attributes.title: An Open-source Anthropomorphic Robot Hand System: HRI Hand
attributes.description:
This repository include all hardware design file of the HRI hand.
The software is upload the follow github link:
https://github.com/MrLacuqer/HRI-hand-firmware.git
https://github.com/MrLacuqer/HRI-Hand-ROS.git

q1.value: An Open-source Anthropomorphic Robot Hand System: HRI Hand

q3.value: We present an open-source anthropomorphic robot hand system called HRI hand. Our robot hand system was developed with a focus on the end-effector role of the collaborative robot manipulator. HRI hand is a research platform that can be built at a lower price (approximately $500, using only 3D printing) than commercial end-effectors. Moreover, it was designed as a two four-bar linkage for the under-actuated mechanism and provides pre-shaping motion similar to the human hand prior to touching an object. A URDF, python node, and rviz package is also provided to support the Robot Operating System (ROS). All hardware CAD design files and software source codes have been released and can be easily assembled and modified. The system proposed in this paper is developed with a five-finger structure, but each finger is modularized, so it can be developed with end-effectors of various shapes depending on the shape of the palm.

q4.value: The system proposed in this paper is developed with a five-finger structure, but each finger is modularized, so it can be developed with end-effectors of various shapes depending on the shape of the palm. For example, it is possible to construct various types of end-effectors depending on the researcher's purpose, such as two-fingered grippers with two fingers or three-fingered grippers with three fingers. For those interested in implementing a variety of robot applications using the proposed system, we would strongly encourage contacting the corresponding author to discuss potential collaboration.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Since the proposed robot hand imitated the human hand, the four fingers, excluding the thumb, consist of DIP, PIP, and MCP joints. attributes.title: Directional prepositions and event boundary conceptualization-English to and towards
attributes.description: The current study investigates the use of two English directional prepositions (i.e., to and towards). We explores two factors that might affect the use of the two prepositions: intentionality of the moving figure and the addressee status.

question2a.value: -Norm activation: categorical variable with four levels (none, descriptive, injunctive, and social), between-participant

question2b.value:
1.	Target-request acceptance (yes or no): Commitment to volunteer to distribute flyers as part of an association of discrimination prevention towards individuals of foreign origin
Binomial variable: yes or no

2.	Amount of volunteering:  Time that participants will spend to distribute flyers (from 1 to 8 half-hours).
Ordinal variable with eight levels (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8)

3.	Indicators of discriminatory behaviors: Cyberball is recording (Pryor, Reeder, Wesselmann, Williams, & Wirth, 2013): 

-	The number of tosses before inclusion (NTBI): A NTBI index was scored 0 if the participants tossed the ball to the target at the first opportunity. The NTBI index was scored 1 if participants waited until the second time, they caught the ball to toss to the target, 2 if they waited until the third time, and so on. Thus, the NTBI index reflects participants’ conscious choices of when to begin including the target in the game. 
Ordinal variable with three levels (0, 1, 2) 

-	The hesitation given inclusion (HGI): It represents the average latency across trials in throwing the ball to the target player. Latency scores were derived from subtracting the clock time when the participant received the ball from the subsequent clock time when the next player received the ball. Hesitating when throwing the ball to a target person is a subtle behavior and would seem unlikely to be consciously controlled by participants. Only latency scores involving the target as recipient of the ball contributed to the HGI index.
Continuous variable

-	The cumulative number of tosses (CNT) to each player form the participants across the entire game.
Continuous variable

question10b.value:
1.	Participants 

The participants will be undergraduate students of University of Caen Normandy (France). 


2.	Material 

Manipulation of norm activation 

To activate the descriptive norm, we will use the ingroup norm of anti-discrimination by using the Gabarrot, Falomir-Pichastor, & Mugny’s material (2009). Participants will be informed about the results of a supposed previous study carried out with a representative sample of University of Caen Normandy undergraduate students. These results will be displayed in a graphical form, using percentages of response to one question. Two graphics will supposedly concern the actual behavior of this sample when they were asked to allocate resources to two groups: the French people of French origin and the French people's foreign origin. The results will activate an anti-discrimination descriptive norm (Cialdini et al., 1990) by showing that the majority of undergraduate students do not favor the French people of French origin over foreign origin. Most of them opt for an egalitarian distribution of resources in terms of housing (respectively 89.26% vs. 5.9% inegalitarian distribution and 4.8% did not know) or education benefits (respectively, 82.25%, vs. 12.45% inegalitarian distribution and 5.3% did not know). Then, to be sure that the supposed results will be taken into account by the participants, they will be asked to answer comprehension questions, as recommended by (Smith & Louis, 2008). 

To activate the injunctive norm, we will use the same material used for descriptive norm (Gabarrot, Falomir-Pichastor, & Mugny, 2009). However, both graphs will supposedly be about the perceived legitimacy of social policies favoring the French people of French origin over the foreign origin. The results will activate an anti-discrimination injunctive norm by showing that the majority of University of Caen Normandy undergraduate students do not consider favoring French people of French origin over the foreign origin in terms of housing (respectively 89.26% vs. 5.9% legitimate and 4.8% did not know) or education benefits (respectively, 82.25%, vs. 12.45% legitimate and 5.3% did not know), to be legitimate. Then, to be sure that the supposed results will be taken into account by the participants, they will be asked to answer comprehension questions, as recommended by (Smith & Louis, 2008).

To activate the social norms, participants will carry out both the descriptive norm activation (one graphic for housing and education benefits, respectively 89.26% vs. 5.9% inegalitarian distribution and 4.8% did not know) and injunctive norm activation (one graphic for housing and education benefits, respectively, 82.25%, vs. 12.45% legitimate and 5.3% did not know).

Recall of past behaviors (the transgression phase). 
Participants filled out a questionnaire concerning their past behaviors in discrimination situations. It included five discrimination situations  (i.e., keep away, avoidance behavior, criticizing, disregard, and staring at). They were asked to give some details about these situations, such as when it happened for the last time, where they were, and who were concerned by the situation. This classically used questionnaire (Fried, 1998) allows to ease the participants’ transgression recall in order to make them conscious of their own counter-normative acts.

Dependent measures 

Target-request acceptance: Participants will be asked if they accept to distribute flyers as part of an association of discrimination prevention towards individuals of foreign origin. The higher the likelihood to accept, the higher induced-hypocrisy effect. 

Amount of volunteering: Participants will be asked how much time they will be willing to spend to distribute flyers (from 1 to 8 half-hours). The higher the score, the higher the induced-hypocrisy effect. 

Discriminatory behaviors (measured via the Cyberball game). The participants will sit in front of a computer and will receive instructions on playing a Cyberball game (Pryor et al., 2013). Cyberball will be described to the participants as a mental visualization task where participants will be asked to imagine playing an actual game of “catch” with other participants. In Cyberball, an animated ball is tossed from person to person on a computer screen. In these four-person games, the other three people will be represented on screen by three animated “Cyberboy” figures. Above or to the side of each figure will have a head-shot photo of each player along with her first name. Players will be arranged in a circle on the screen. Play will begin with the person to the left tossing the ball. When the participants receive the ball, they could elect to toss it to any of the other players by clicking on the photo of the person with the computer mouse. The other three players will be “virtual confederates,” as their play will be pre-programmed by the experimenter. The Cyberball game will be programmed to carry on for 60 ball tosses. Unbeknownst to participants, one of the three confederates is the Target Player, while the other two are designated Other Player 1 and Other Player 2, respectively. Using the photographs and the first name described above, the Target player is a French people of foreign origin while the other two players are French people of French origin. The Target Player’s position on the screen is always on the left of the participant. The Target Player and the other two confederates randomly alternate among all of the players in their tosses throughout the game. To control the gender effect, all man's participants will play with a man Target and man other Players (Figure 1), and all woman’s participants will play with a woman Target and woman other Players (Figure 2).
Based on the recording of two information (i.e., the which player receives each toss, and the computer clock time at the point the ball is received) the cyberball game will allow to have three indicators of discriminatory behaviors: 
-	The number of tosses before inclusion (NTBI): A NTBI index will score 0 if the participants toss the ball to the target at the first opportunity. The NTBI index will score 1 if participants wait until the second time, they will catch the ball to toss to the target, 2 if they will wait until the third time, and so on. Thus, the NTBI will reflect participants’ conscious choices of when to begin including the target in the game. The lesser the score, the higher the induced-hypocrisy effect.
-	The hesitation given inclusion (HGI): It will represent the average latency across trials in throwing the ball to the target player. Latency scores will derive from subtracting the clock time when the participant receive the ball from the subsequent clock time when the next player receive the ball. Hesitating when throwing the ball to a target person is a subtle behavior and would seem unlikely to be consciously controlled by participants. Only latency scores involving the target as recipient of the ball will contribute to the HGI index. The lesser the score, the higher the induced-hypocrisy effect.
-	The cumulative number of tosses (CNT) to each player form the participants across the entire game. The higher the score, the higher the induced-hypocrisy effect.



3.	Procedure 

Participants will be approached individually and will be given an informed consent for their participation in a study conducting on the understanding of intergroup relations. All participants will be naïve to the hypothesis of the experiment. They will be equally balanced across the following five norm inconsistency conditions: none, descriptive, injunctive, personal, and social. 

In the “none” norm activation condition, the dependent measures will be proposed directly to the participants: to take part in an association in order to distribute anti-discrimination awareness flyers (i.e., the target request), the amount of volunteering to do it, and cyberball game (i.e., discriminatory behaviors indicators).

In the three other conditions (i.e., the conditions of descriptive, injunctive, and social norms activation), participants will begin to carry out the normative phase of Induced-Hypocrisy paradigm – which is different according to the three conditions - and will then fill out the transgression phase (i.e., a questionnaire, concerning their past discriminatory behaviors, which is the same across these conditions). At the end of the experimental, dependent variables will be assessed.

All participants will then complete a socio-demographic questionnaire before being debriefed and thanked for their participation. The entire procedure will take approximately 25 minutes.

question1a.value:
H1a: The number of participants who will accept the target-request will be lower in “none” norm activation condition than the three other conditions.

H1b: The participants’ amount of volunteering will be lower in “none” norm activation condition than the three other conditions.

H1c: The discriminatory behaviors indicators of participants will be higher in “none” norm activation condition than the three other conditions. 

H2a: The number of participants who will accept the target-request will  depend on the norms’ number involved in the inconsistency, regardless of the norms’ type: more there are norms transgressed, the greater the IH effect is. More especially, the number of participants who will accept the target-request will increase as follows: “none” norm activation condition then descriptive and injunctive conditions, and then social condition.

H2b: The participants’ amount of volunteering will depend on the norms’ number involved in the inconsistency, regardless of the norms’ type: more there are norms transgressed, the greater the IH effect is. More especially, the participants’ amount of volunteering will increase as follows: “none” norm activation condition then descriptive and injunctive conditions, and then social condition.

H3c: The discriminatory behaviors indicators of participants will depend on the norms’ number involved in the inconsistency, regardless of the norms’ type: more there are norms transgressed, the greater the IH effect is. More especially, the discrimination score will decrease as follows: “none” norm activation condition then descriptive and injunctive conditions, and then social condition.

question3a.value: We will use material which has already been used in previous studies to manipulate norms and inconsistency to it. Please note that a pre-test of one of our previous study confirmed the successful manipulation of this variable.

question5a.value:
Despite the public policy gets hold of the issue of discrimination - to treat in a different way an individual  based on their group membership (Whitley & Kite, 2013) - since 2001 in France,  and the presence of anti-discrimination norm (Whithey & Kite, 2013), discriminatory behaviors still are currently in our society (e.g., Vautier, 2015). This study aims to prevent discriminatory behaviors through the Induced-Hypocrisy (IH) paradigm (Aronson, Fried, & Stone, 1991).

The induced-hypocrisy (IH) paradigm (Aronson, Fried, & Stone, 1991) is a two-step procedure: 1) promoting a norm and 2) recalling past transgressions of this norm. This inconsistency leads people to adopt behaviors in accordance with the promoted norm (e.g., Fointiat, 2008; Sénémeaud, Mange, Fointiat, & Somat, 2014). Because of the main explanation of IH, which is based on the self-consistency theory (i.e., behavior change would allow to restore the self-concept threatened by the recall of past transgression; Aronson, 1992), few studies have investigated the role of norms. However, the theory of deviation from the norm (Liégeois et al., 2017) tends to make more central the role of norms in IH by viewing the behavioral change as the reduction of the perceived gap between a norm and a behavior. In line with this theory, recent research showed the moderating role of social norms in IH paradigm: when they are reinforced (weakened), higher (lesser), the IH effect is (Mauduy, Priolo, Margas, & Sénémeaud, 2020). Furthermore, two kinds of social norms – descriptive and injunctive (Cialdini, Kallgren, & Reno, 1991) – influence behaviors and the combined use of them reinforces their effect (Cialdini & Trost, 1998). Thus, this study aims to deepen the moderating role of social norms in the IH paradigm by testing the contribution of each social norm as well as their association with the IH effect.

question1c.value:
Target-request acceptance: It will be attributed the number “1” for participants who will accept the target-request, and the number “0” for the participants who will not accept it.

Amount of volunteering: Scores between 1 and 8 will be attributed to participants, denoting the amount of time they accept to spend to distribute flyers (a score of 1 means halh an hour). 

Discriminatory behaviors indicators (computed scores): 
-	The number of tosses before inclusion (NTBI): A NTBI index will score 0 if the participants toss the ball to the target at the first opportunity. The NTBI index will score 1 if participants wait until the second time, they will catch the ball to toss to the target, 2 if they will wait until the third time, and so on. Thus, the NTBI will reflect participants’ conscious choices of when to begin including the target in the game.
-	The hesitation given inclusion (HGI): It will represent the average latency across trials in throwing the ball to the target player. Latency scores will derive from subtracting the clock time when the participant receive the ball from the subsequent clock time when the next player receive the ball. Only latency scores involving the target as recipient of the ball will contribute to the HGI index.
-	The cumulative number of tosses (CNT) to each player form the participants across the entire game. Only the number of tosses to the target player from the participants will contribute to the CNT index.

question2c.value:
In order to test our hypotheses, data will be analyzed using contrast analyses, as recommended by many authors (Abelson, 1995; Brauer & McClelland, 2005; Judd & McClelland, 1989; Rosenthal, Rosnow, & Rubin, 2000). The use of contrast analyses will allow us to test specific hypotheses more efficiently than omnibus tests. First, the hypothesis 1 will be test with the following first contrast: none = -3; descriptive = 1; injunctive = 1; social = 1. Second, the hypothesis 2 will be tested with the following second contrast: none = 0; descriptive = -1; injunctive = -1; social = 2. The third contrast (none = 0; descriptive = -1; injunctive = 1; social = 0) is residual. To conclude that data are consistent with our two hypotheses, two conditions will have to be satisfied. First, the two first contrast will have to explain a significant part of variance and the residual contrast will have to be non-significant.

The percentage of participants who will accept to commit as part of discrimination prevention association will be analyzed using logistic regression procedures, with the three contrasts of norm activation variable as predictors and target-request acceptance as predicted variable. 

For the amount of volunteering: An ordinal regression (sequential model, cf., Burkner & Vuorre, 2019) will be performed with the three contrasts of norm activation variable as predictors and the eight levels amount of volunteering as variable predicted.

For the number of tosses before inclusion (NTBI) index: An ordinal regression (sequential model, cf., Burkner & Vuorre, 2019) will be performed with the three contrasts of norm activation variable as predictors and the three levels of NTBI as variable predicted. 
For the hesitation given inclusion (HGI) index: A linear regression will be performed on HGI index with the three contrasts of norm activation variable as predictors. 
For the cumulative number of tosses (CNT): A linear regression will be performed on CNT index with the three contrasts of norm activation variable as predictors.

DVc: Discriminatory behaviors indicators

-	The hesitation given inclusion (HGI)
-	The cumulative number of tosses (CNT)

Participants filled out a questionnaire concerning their past behaviors in discrimination situations. It included five discrimination situations  (i.e., keep away, avoidance behavior, criticizing, disregard, and staring at). They were asked to give some details about these situations, such as when it happened for the last time, where they were, and who were concerned by the situation. This classically used questionnaire (Fried, 1998) allows to ease the participants’ transgression recall in order to make them conscious of their own counter-normative acts.

Dependent measures 

Target-request acceptance: Participants will be asked if they accept to distribute flyers as part of an association of discrimination prevention towards individuals of foreign origin. The higher the likelihood to accept, the higher induced-hypocrisy effect. 

Amount of volunteering: Participants will be asked how much time they will be willing to spend to distribute flyers (from 1 to 8 half-hours). The higher the score, the higher the induced-hypocrisy effect. 

Discriminatory behaviors (measured via the Cyberball game). The participants will sit in front of a computer and will receive instructions on playing a Cyberball game (Pryor et al., 2013). Cyberball will be described to the participants as a mental visualization task where participants will be asked to imagine playing an actual game of “catch” with other participants. In Cyberball, an animated ball is tossed from person to person on a computer screen. In these four-person games, the other three people will be represented on screen by three animated “Cyberboy” figures. Above or to the side of each figure will have a head-shot photo of each player along with her first name. Players will be arranged in a circle on the screen. Play will begin with the person to the left tossing the ball. When the participants receive the ball, they could elect to toss it to any of the other players by clicking on the photo of the person with the computer mouse. The other three players will be “virtual confederates,” as their play will be pre-programmed by the experimenter. The Cyberball game will be programmed to carry on for 60 ball tosses. Unbeknownst to participants, one of the three confederates is the Target Player, while the other two are designated Other Player 1 and Other Player 2, respectively. Using the photographs and the first name described above, the Target player is a French people of foreign origin while the other two players are French people of French origin. The Target Player’s position on the screen is always on the left of the participant. The Target Player and the other two confederates randomly alternate among all of the players in their tosses throughout the game. To control the gender effect, all man's participants will play with a man Target and man other Players (Figure 1), and all woman’s participants will play with a woman Target and woman other Players (Figure 2).
Based on the recording of two information (i.e., the which player receives each toss, and the computer clock time at the point the ball is received) the cyberball game will allow to have three indicators of discriminatory behaviors: 
-	The number of tosses before inclusion (NTBI): A NTBI index will score 0 if the participants toss the ball to the target at the first opportunity. The NTBI index will score 1 if participants wait until the second time, they will catch the ball to toss to the target, 2 if they will wait until the third time, and so on. Thus, the NTBI will reflect participants’ conscious choices of when to begin including the target in the game. The lesser the score, the higher the induced-hypocrisy effect.
-	The hesitation given inclusion (HGI): It will represent the average latency across trials in throwing the ball to the target player. Latency scores will derive from subtracting the clock time when the participant receive the ball from the subsequent clock time when the next player receive the ball. Hesitating when throwing the ball to a target person is a subtle behavior and would seem unlikely to be consciously controlled by participants. Only latency scores involving the target as recipient of the ball will contribute to the HGI index. The lesser the score, the higher the induced-hypocrisy effect.
-	The cumulative number of tosses (CNT) to each player form the participants across the entire game. The higher the score, the higher the induced-hypocrisy effect.



3.	Procedure 

Participants will be approached individually and will be given an informed consent for their participation in a study conducting on the understanding of intergroup relations. All participants will be naïve to the hypothesis of the experiment. They will be equally balanced across the following five norm inconsistency conditions: none, descriptive, injunctive, personal, and social. 

In the “none” norm activation condition, the dependent measures will be proposed directly to the participants: to take part in an association in order to distribute anti-discrimination awareness flyers (i.e., the target request), the amount of volunteering to do it, and cyberball game (i.e., discriminatory behaviors indicators).

In the three other conditions (i.e., the conditions of descriptive, injunctive, and social norms activation), participants will begin to carry out the normative phase of Induced-Hypocrisy paradigm – which is different according to the three conditions - and will then fill out the transgression phase (i.e., a questionnaire, concerning their past discriminatory behaviors, which is the same across these conditions). At the end of the experimental, dependent variables will be assessed.

All participants will then complete a socio-demographic questionnaire before being debriefed and thanked for their participation. The entire procedure will take approximately 25 minutes.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
Target-request acceptance: It will be attributed the number “1” for participants who will accept the target-request, and the number “0” for the participants who will not accept it.

Amount of volunteering: Scores between 1 and 8 will be attributed to participants, denoting the amount of time they accept to spend to distribute flyers (a score of 1 means halh an hour). 

Discriminatory behaviors indicators (computed scores): 
-	The number of tosses before inclusion (NTBI): A NTBI index will score 0 if the participants toss the ball to the target at the first opportunity. The NTBI index will score 1 if participants wait until the second time, they will catch the ball to toss to the target, 2 if they will wait until the third time, and so on. Thus, the NTBI will reflect participants’ conscious choices of when to begin including the target in the game.
-	The hesitation given inclusion (HGI): It will represent the average latency across trials in throwing the ball to the target player. Latency scores will derive from subtracting the clock time when the participant receive the ball from the subsequent clock time when the next player receive the ball. Only latency scores involving the target as recipient of the ball will contribute to the HGI index.
-	The cumulative number of tosses (CNT) to each player form the participants across the entire game. Only the number of tosses to the target player from the participants will contribute to the CNT index.

In order to test our hypotheses, data will be analyzed using contrast analyses, as recommended by many authors (Abelson, 1995; Brauer & McClelland, 2005; Judd & McClelland, 1989; Rosenthal, Rosnow, & Rubin, 2000). The use of contrast analyses will allow us to test specific hypotheses more efficiently than omnibus tests. First, the hypothesis 1 will be test with the following first contrast: none = -3; descriptive = 1; injunctive = 1; social = 1. Second, the hypothesis 2 will be tested with the following second contrast: none = 0; descriptive = -1; injunctive = -1; social = 2. The third contrast (none = 0; descriptive = -1; injunctive = 1; social = 0) is residual. To conclude that data are consistent with our two hypotheses, two conditions will have to be satisfied. First, the two first contrast will have to explain a significant part of variance and the residual contrast will have to be non-significant.

The percentage of participants who will accept to commit as part of discrimination prevention association will be analyzed using logistic regression procedures, with the three contrasts of norm activation variable as predictors and target-request acceptance as predicted variable. 

For the amount of volunteering: An ordinal regression (sequential model, cf., Burkner & Vuorre, 2019) will be performed with the three contrasts of norm activation variable as predictors and the eight levels amount of volunteering as variable predicted.

For the number of tosses before inclusion (NTBI) index: An ordinal regression (sequential model, cf., Burkner & Vuorre, 2019) will be performed with the three contrasts of norm activation variable as predictors and the three levels of NTBI as variable predicted. 
For the hesitation given inclusion (HGI) index: A linear regression will be performed on HGI index with the three contrasts of norm activation variable as predictors. 
For the cumulative number of tosses (CNT): A linear regression will be performed on CNT index with the three contrasts of norm activation variable as predictors.

IV : Norm activation 
DVa: Target-request acceptance 
DVb: Amount of volunteering
DVc: Discriminatory behaviors indicators 
-	The number of tosses before inclusion (NTBI)
-	The hesitation given inclusion (HGI)
-	The cumulative number of tosses (CNT)

q1.value: Defining consistency: understanding the lay understanding of between statement consistency

q2.value: Charlotte A. Hudson, Professor Aldert Vrij, Lucy Akehurst, LORRAINE HOPE

q3.value: The deception consistency heuristic proposes that truthful statements will be consistent across interviews and that inconsistencies between statements are indicative of deception (Granhag & Strömwall, 1999). Although research has found little evidence for the use of this so-called consistency heuristic (Vredeveldt, van Koppen, & Granhag, 2014), people typically strongly believe that inconsistency is associated with deception (Bogaard & Meijer, 2017; Masip et al., 2018). However, the academic conceptualisation of consistency does not seem to align with layperson understanding of consistency (Hudson, Vrij, Akehurst, Hope, & Satchell, under review). That is, research suggests that experts who code statements for consistency in detail, with dedicated time and resources, do not examine the same aspects of the statement as laypersons when they globally identify ‘consistency’. As such, we will examine what laypeople mean when they report using consistency to inform their veracity judgements.  Using this information, we will develop a coding scheme for cues to consistency (the Layperson Understanding of Consistency Key; LUCK), and test whether consistency judgements can accurately classify truthful and deceptive statements when this coding scheme is used.

q4.value: This is an exploratory study, and as such we do not have any formal hypotheses.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value:
Our main research questions are as follows:
•	Which key aspects of a statement characterise (in)consistency?
•	Can the LUCK scheme reliably differentiate between consistent and inconsistent statements? 
•	Will the classification of consistency using the LUCK scheme align with the veracity of the statements?
Our secondary research question is:
•	Will the LUCK scheme more accurately differentiate between truths and lies than the scientific coding of repetitions, reminiscences, omissions, and contradictions?


Part One of the study will be a mixed design. Participants will be asked to either provide a truthful or deceptive statement (to be used to test the coding scheme in Part Two of the study), and asked to rate and comment on four pairs of statements for consistency (to be analysed using a thematic analysis). 
Part Two of the study will be testing the coding scheme, using a within subjects design. Coders will be asked to classify 30 pairs of statements (generated in Part One) as either consistent or inconsistent, using the coding scheme generated from the thematic analysis.

q9.value: Participants in Part One of the study will be randomly allocated to provide either a truthful or deceptive statement (to be coded in Part Two), and randomly presented four sets of paired statements, from a bank of a potential 16 sets of pair statements. Random allocation will be done by Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
After completing their own accounts in Part One of the study, participants will be asked to read four sets of paired statements (hereby referred to as ‘stimulus materials’) collected from a previous study, and highlight any aspects that indicate (in)consistency.  This is not for the explicit purpose of detecting deception, therefore participants will be informed that we are interested in how people understand consistency across statements. Stimulus materials used in Part One of the study are the same as those used in Hudson et al. (under review). To generate stimulus materials for rating, 17 individuals (6 male, 11 female, aged 18-52, Mage = 28.44, SDage = 9.35) were randomly allocated to either telling the truth or lying about a memorable event that took place in the past two years. They were interviewed by an instruction-blind interviewer. Truth tellers were asked to recall a positive memorable event that occurred within the past two years, and were given examples such as of going on holiday or having a celebratory birthday dinner. They were instructed to choose an event that they were comfortable talking about honestly and could remember in detail. Those who were asked to lie were asked to invent the details of a positive memorable event provided by the researcher (for example “Spending Christmas on a beach”). Following a delay of one week, all participants returned to be interviewed by the same interviewer for a second time. Participants were either truthful in both interviews or deceptive in both interviews. Interviews were audio recorded and conducted using a script, featuring one open ended request for the interviewee to tell the interviewer everything about their memorable event. Participants of the previous study were aware their statements would be used in subsequent research, and consented to their statements being used in this way. Any identifiable features that were provided in the statements (such as names) were changed for anonymity. 
The transcripts will be used as stimulus materials to prompt participants to highlight features of the stimulus materials that they find (in)consistent. We will only use the first 16 sets of the paired statements, and disregarded the statements provided by the 17th participant. All 17 participants gave written consent for their statements to be used in future research. An even number of stimulus materials will be selected to ensure that an equal number of truth teller and liar statements could be presented. Participants will be randomly allocated four pairs of stimulus materials to consider out of a bank of 16 pairs of stimulus materials. Participants will not know the veracity of any of the stimulus materials, and will not be asked to make a veracity judgement of the stimulus materials.

question.value:
Part One
Materials: Part One will utilise an online questionnaire (Qualtrics) where participants will be asked to write two short accounts about a positive memorable event (for example, their last vacation or a friend’s wedding) in no more than 500 words (accounts will be limited to prevent order effects for reporting the same account twice). Participants will be asked to either lie or tell the truth in their accounts. Truth tellers will be asked to provide two completely honest accounts about the same event that they experienced in the past two years. Liars will be asked to completely fabricate two accounts about the same event that they have never experienced. These two accounts are being generated for coding in Part Two of the study, and consequently we discuss how the statements will be used there. 
In between providing the two accounts, participants will be asked to complete the HEXACO-60 personality questionnaire as a filler task. The HEXACO-60 is a well-established tool consisting of 60 questions measuring Honesty-Humility (H), Emotionality (E), Extraversion (X), Agreeableness (A), Conscientiousness (C), and Openness to Experience (O). The HEXACO-60 (Ashton & Lee, 2009; Appendix Four) questionnaire takes approximately 12 minutes to complete. 
After completing their own accounts, they will be asked to read four sets of paired statements (hereby referred to as ‘stimulus materials’) collected from a previous study, and highlight any aspects that indicate (in)consistency.  This is not for the explicit purpose of detecting deception, therefore participants will be informed that we are interested in how people understand consistency across statements. Stimulus materials used in Part One of the study are the same as those used in Hudson et al. (under review). To generate stimulus materials for rating, 17 individuals (6 male, 11 female, aged 18-52, Mage = 28.44, SDage = 9.35) were randomly allocated to either telling the truth or lying about a memorable event that took place in the past two years. They were interviewed by an instruction-blind interviewer. Truth tellers were asked to recall a positive memorable event that occurred within the past two years, and were given examples such as of going on holiday or having a celebratory birthday dinner. They were instructed to choose an event that they were comfortable talking about honestly and could remember in detail. Those who were asked to lie were asked to invent the details of a positive memorable event provided by the researcher (for example “Spending Christmas on a beach”). Following a delay of one week, all participants returned to be interviewed by the same interviewer for a second time. Participants were either truthful in both interviews or deceptive in both interviews. Interviews were audio recorded and conducted using a script, featuring one open ended request for the interviewee to tell the interviewer everything about their memorable event. Participants of the previous study were aware their statements would be used in subsequent research, and consented to their statements being used in this way. Any identifiable features that were provided in the statements (such as names) were changed for anonymity. 
The transcripts will be used as stimulus materials to prompt participants to highlight features of the stimulus materials that they find (in)consistent. We will only use the first 16 sets of the paired statements, and disregarded the statements provided by the 17th participant. All 17 participants gave written consent for their statements to be used in future research. An even number of stimulus materials will be selected to ensure that an equal number of truth teller and liar statements could be presented. Participants will be randomly allocated four pairs of stimulus materials to consider out of a bank of 16 pairs of stimulus materials. Participants will not know the veracity of any of the stimulus materials, and will not be asked to make a veracity judgement of the stimulus materials.
Procedure: After participants have expressed interest in the study they will be emailed a copy of the Participant Information Sheet (Appendix One) and consent form (Appendix Two) at least 24 hours prior to the study session, to make sure they have all information available to them before they arrange times to participate. We will recruit 30 participants (15 truth tellers and 15 liars). On the day of the study, all participants will attend the laboratory at a pre-organised time. All participants will again be given a copy of the Information Sheet to read. They will then be verbally informed of the procedure by the researcher (Oral Consent Script, Appendix Three), and asked to thoroughly read the information sheet and informed consent form before signing. Participants will be given a copy of their signed consent form to keep and provided with an opportunity to ask any questions. Participants will then be randomly allocated to a truth telling or a lying group to provide their accounts. 
Truth tellers will be asked to recall a positive memorable event that occurred within the past two years, and we will provide the examples of going on holiday or having a celebratory birthday dinner (however, it will be clear that these are examples, and they are not limited to these options). They will be instructed to choose an event that they are comfortable writing about completely honestly and can remember in detail. Liars will be asked to invent a positive memorable event, and told that it should have occurred within the past two years. They will also be provided with the examples of going on holiday or having a celebratory birthday dinner. Both truth tellers and liars will be asked not to include any details in their account that could be used to identify them.
Data will be collected using Qualtrics. Participants will be asked to write either their truthful or deceptive first account of their memorable event as a response to an open-ended question, after which they will be presented with the HEXACO-60. After completing the HEXACO-60 personality questionnaire as a filler task, participants will be asked to think about the event they previously reported. A context reinstatement instruction will inform them to consider what sensory information they can recall, such as things they saw, could hear, or could smell. This instruction will encourage participants to remember the event, rather than just thinking about their previous account. After 30 seconds of the screen displaying this instruction, participants will be asked to again write another account about the same experience.
Once participants have provided two accounts regarding the same memorable event, they will then be asked to consider some other participants’ memorable events (i.e. the stimulus materials). The participant will be given a paper copy of two statements and asked to rate how consistent they believe the statements to be on a scale of 0% (highly inconsistent) to 100% (highly consistent). Ratings will be taken on a 0% - 100% scale to allow us to calculate an average “cut off” point, to differentiate how (in)consistent a statement needs to be to be considered (in)consistent based upon the comments on the stimulus materials. Once they have made their judgement, participants will then be asked to use a highlighter pen to notate a few key aspects of the statements that they consider to be (in)consistent, and add written notes to explain why they think that part is (in)consistent. Participants will be asked to do this for four pairs of statements, and then asked to write a brief statement explaining what they believe consistency is. These stimulus materials are taken from Hudson et al. (under review). This statement and the notes will be used in a thematic analysis to develop a clearer picture of how laypeople understand consistency and the LUCK scheme.
A pilot study will be run with 5 participants to test the methodology and ensure clarity within the instructions. It is anticipated that the study will take no more than 45 minutes.

Part Two
Materials: The thematic analysis conducted in Part One of the study will be used to inform a coding scheme based upon the layperson understanding of consistency (the Layperson Understanding of Consistency Key; LUCK). The LUCK scheme will tested for reliability using the memorable event accounts collected from the participants in Part One of the study by a team of independent coders.
Procedure: Six independent coders will be asked to categorise the 30 pairs of statements collected in Part One as either consistent or inconsistent using the LUCK scheme derived from Part One of the study. Coders will be blind to statement veracity and asked to make holistic decisions on whether a statement is consistent or inconsistent, based upon the LUCK scheme derived from Part One of the study. Coders will also be asked to code for the number of repetitions, reminiscences, omissions, and contradictions found within a statement. We will mathematically calculate whether a statement is consistent or inconsistent using the proportion of inconsistent details (i.e. omissions, reminiscence, and contradictions) to consistent details (i.e. repetitions).

q13.value:
Part One
The ability to read and understand English to a high level is required to complete the accounts and to read the stimulus materials. All participants will need to confirm that they are aged 18+ years. We anticipate recruiting 30 participants during Part One of the project. As the data from participants will be analysed using a thematic analysis (Braun & Clarke, 2006), a smaller sample size is required, due to the richness of the data. Braun and Clarke (2013) recommend a sample size of 10 – 50 for participant generated text. As each participant will be generating text regarding four separate stimulus materials as well as giving a statement about their definition of consistency, we will recruit 30 participants to participate in Part One of the study. Participants will be paid £5 for their time, and will volunteers will be recruited using opportunity sampling. Data collection will take place in February 2020.

Part Two
This research study will use a sample of at least six students, participating as part of the Research Based Learning course requirement or as volunteers wishing to get more research experience. We will have a minimum of six coders trained in the LUCK scheme developed from Part One of the study who are asked to classify the 30 accounts collected in Part One as either “consistent” or “inconsistent” using the LUCK scheme (a total of 180 observations). A power analysis using a medium effect size of ω = .30 suggests the study will achieve a power of .89. A medium effect size was estimated to reflect the medium effect size found by Granhag and Strömwall (2000). Part Two of the study will take place in March 2020.

question.value:
Participants in Part One of the study will be randomly allocated to tell the truth or lie about a memorable event. They will also be provided with a random selection of four statement pairs (out of a bank of 16 statement pairs) to examine for between statement consistency. Participants will be randomly allocated to conditions by computer generation (i.e. the questionnaire used to collect the data will randomly allocate participants into conditions).

There is no manipulation in Part Two of the study.

Part One
Participants’ comments explaining which parts of the stimulus materials were (in)consistent will be examined in relation to their statement about what they believe consistency is (hereby referred to as “data”). Data will be analysed using a thematic analysis (Braun & Clark, 2006). First, we will familiarise ourselves with the data, by reading and re-reading the data, and identifying patterns that occur. Detailed notes will be taken to generate initial codes. From this we will make inferences about what the codes mean. Codes will then be combined into overarching themes to accurately represent the data, and we will establish how the themes support the data. Each theme will be clearly defined, and we will establish how each theme contributes to the holistic understanding of consistency. The themes will be reduced down to a clear and coherent set of LUCK coding instructions for Part Two of the study.
Part Two
To test the effectiveness of the LUCK scheme in comparison to the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme, a minimum of six independent coders will be asked to rate 30 pairs of accounts (collected in Part One of the study) as either consistent or inconsistent using the LUCK scheme and the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme. Interrater reliability of application of each coding scheme for each of the 30 pairs of statements will be calculated using Cohen’s kappa, to determine reliability of the scales. Reliability will be accepted at κ = .80. Following this, chi-squared analyses will determine whether rater classification of consistent/inconsistent significantly reflects the known veracity of the 30 pairs of statements for the LUCK scheme and the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme. There will be four cells for analysis: “truthful statements categorised as consistent”, “truthful statements categorised as inconsistent”, “deceptive statements categorised as consistent”, and “deceptive statements categorised as inconsistent”. To test whether the consistency heuristic correctly reflects statement veracity, we will collapse the four cells into two. We will combine the cell “truthful statements categorised as consistent” and “deceptive statements categorised as inconsistent”, which will represent the consistency heuristic. We will also combine the cells “truthful statements categorised as inconsistent” and “deceptive statements categorised as consistent”, which will reflect the repeat versus reconstruct hypothesis. We will seek to determine whether there is a significant difference between the number of statements that are correctly classified using the consistency heuristic coding scheme compared to the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme. Significance will be accepted at p < 05.

Part Two
To test the effectiveness of the LUCK scheme in comparison to the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme, a minimum of six independent coders will be asked to rate 30 pairs of accounts (collected in Part One of the study) as either consistent or inconsistent using the LUCK scheme and the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme. Interrater reliability of application of each coding scheme for each of the 30 pairs of statements will be calculated using Cohen’s kappa, to determine reliability of the scales. Reliability will be accepted at κ = .80. Following this, chi-squared analyses will determine whether rater classification of consistent/inconsistent significantly reflects the known veracity of the 30 pairs of statements for the LUCK scheme and the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme. There will be four cells for analysis: “truthful statements categorised as consistent”, “truthful statements categorised as inconsistent”, “deceptive statements categorised as consistent”, and “deceptive statements categorised as inconsistent”. To test whether the consistency heuristic correctly reflects statement veracity, we will collapse the four cells into two. We will combine the cell “truthful statements categorised as consistent” and “deceptive statements categorised as inconsistent”, which will represent the consistency heuristic. We will also combine the cells “truthful statements categorised as inconsistent” and “deceptive statements categorised as consistent”, which will reflect the repeat versus reconstruct hypothesis. We will seek to determine whether there is a significant difference between the number of statements that are correctly classified using the consistency heuristic coding scheme compared to the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme.

Any identifiable features that were provided in the statements (such as names) were changed for anonymity. 
The transcripts will be used as stimulus materials to prompt participants to highlight features of the stimulus materials that they find (in)consistent. We will only use the first 16 sets of the paired statements, and disregarded the statements provided by the 17th participant. All 17 participants gave written consent for their statements to be used in future research. An even number of stimulus materials will be selected to ensure that an equal number of truth teller and liar statements could be presented. Participants will be randomly allocated four pairs of stimulus materials to consider out of a bank of 16 pairs of stimulus materials. Participants will not know the veracity of any of the stimulus materials, and will not be asked to make a veracity judgement of the stimulus materials.
registration_responses.q13:
Part One
The ability to read and understand English to a high level is required to complete the accounts and to read the stimulus materials. All participants will need to confirm that they are aged 18+ years. We anticipate recruiting 30 participants during Part One of the project. As the data from participants will be analysed using a thematic analysis (Braun & Clarke, 2006), a smaller sample size is required, due to the richness of the data. Braun and Clarke (2013) recommend a sample size of 10 – 50 for participant generated text. As each participant will be generating text regarding four separate stimulus materials as well as giving a statement about their definition of consistency, we will recruit 30 participants to participate in Part One of the study. Participants will be paid £5 for their time, and will volunteers will be recruited using opportunity sampling. Data collection will take place in February 2020.

Part Two
This research study will use a sample of at least six students, participating as part of the Research Based Learning course requirement or as volunteers wishing to get more research experience. We will have a minimum of six coders trained in the LUCK scheme developed from Part One of the study who are asked to classify the 30 accounts collected in Part One as either “consistent” or “inconsistent” using the LUCK scheme (a total of 180 observations). A power analysis using a medium effect size of ω = .30 suggests the study will achieve a power of .89. A medium effect size was estimated to reflect the medium effect size found by Granhag and Strömwall (2000). Part Two of the study will take place in March 2020.
registration_responses.q20:
Part One
Participants’ comments explaining which parts of the stimulus materials were (in)consistent will be examined in relation to their statement about what they believe consistency is (hereby referred to as “data”). Data will be analysed using a thematic analysis (Braun & Clark, 2006). First, we will familiarise ourselves with the data, by reading and re-reading the data, and identifying patterns that occur. Detailed notes will be taken to generate initial codes. From this we will make inferences about what the codes mean. Codes will then be combined into overarching themes to accurately represent the data, and we will establish how the themes support the data. Each theme will be clearly defined, and we will establish how each theme contributes to the holistic understanding of consistency. The themes will be reduced down to a clear and coherent set of LUCK coding instructions for Part Two of the study.
registration_responses.q21: Significance will be accepted at p < .05.
registration_responses.q23: If a participant does not complete the questionnaire in Part One of the study, that participant's data will not be included in the analysis.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Our main research questions are as follows:
•	Which key aspects of a statement characterise (in)consistency?
•	Can the LUCK scheme reliably differentiate between consistent and inconsistent statements? 
•	Will the classification of consistency using the LUCK scheme align with the veracity of the statements?
Our secondary research question is:
•	Will the LUCK scheme more accurately differentiate between truths and lies than the scientific coding of repetitions, reminiscences, omissions, and contradictions?


Part One of the study will be a mixed design. Participants will be asked to either provide a truthful or deceptive statement (to be used to test the coding scheme in Part Two of the study), and asked to rate and comment on four pairs of statements for consistency (to be analysed using a thematic analysis). 
Part Two of the study will be testing the coding scheme, using a within subjects design. Coders will be asked to classify 30 pairs of statements (generated in Part One) as either consistent or inconsistent, using the coding scheme generated from the thematic analysis.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Part One
Materials: Part One will utilise an online questionnaire (Qualtrics) where participants will be asked to write two short accounts about a positive memorable event (for example, their last vacation or a friend’s wedding) in no more than 500 words (accounts will be limited to prevent order effects for reporting the same account twice). Participants will be asked to either lie or tell the truth in their accounts. Truth tellers will be asked to provide two completely honest accounts about the same event that they experienced in the past two years. Liars will be asked to completely fabricate two accounts about the same event that they have never experienced. These two accounts are being generated for coding in Part Two of the study, and consequently we discuss how the statements will be used there. 
In between providing the two accounts, participants will be asked to complete the HEXACO-60 personality questionnaire as a filler task. The HEXACO-60 is a well-established tool consisting of 60 questions measuring Honesty-Humility (H), Emotionality (E), Extraversion (X), Agreeableness (A), Conscientiousness (C), and Openness to Experience (O). The HEXACO-60 (Ashton & Lee, 2009; Appendix Four) questionnaire takes approximately 12 minutes to complete. 
After completing their own accounts, they will be asked to read four sets of paired statements (hereby referred to as ‘stimulus materials’) collected from a previous study, and highlight any aspects that indicate (in)consistency.  This is not for the explicit purpose of detecting deception, therefore participants will be informed that we are interested in how people understand consistency across statements. Stimulus materials used in Part One of the study are the same as those used in Hudson et al. (under review). To generate stimulus materials for rating, 17 individuals (6 male, 11 female, aged 18-52, Mage = 28.44, SDage = 9.35) were randomly allocated to either telling the truth or lying about a memorable event that took place in the past two years. They were interviewed by an instruction-blind interviewer. Truth tellers were asked to recall a positive memorable event that occurred within the past two years, and were given examples such as of going on holiday or having a celebratory birthday dinner. They were instructed to choose an event that they were comfortable talking about honestly and could remember in detail. Those who were asked to lie were asked to invent the details of a positive memorable event provided by the researcher (for example “Spending Christmas on a beach”). Following a delay of one week, all participants returned to be interviewed by the same interviewer for a second time. Participants were either truthful in both interviews or deceptive in both interviews. Interviews were audio recorded and conducted using a script, featuring one open ended request for the interviewee to tell the interviewer everything about their memorable event. Participants of the previous study were aware their statements would be used in subsequent research, and consented to their statements being used in this way. Any identifiable features that were provided in the statements (such as names) were changed for anonymity. 
The transcripts will be used as stimulus materials to prompt participants to highlight features of the stimulus materials that they find (in)consistent. We will only use the first 16 sets of the paired statements, and disregarded the statements provided by the 17th participant. All 17 participants gave written consent for their statements to be used in future research. An even number of stimulus materials will be selected to ensure that an equal number of truth teller and liar statements could be presented. Participants will be randomly allocated four pairs of stimulus materials to consider out of a bank of 16 pairs of stimulus materials. Participants will not know the veracity of any of the stimulus materials, and will not be asked to make a veracity judgement of the stimulus materials.
Procedure: After participants have expressed interest in the study they will be emailed a copy of the Participant Information Sheet (Appendix One) and consent form (Appendix Two) at least 24 hours prior to the study session, to make sure they have all information available to them before they arrange times to participate. We will recruit 30 participants (15 truth tellers and 15 liars). On the day of the study, all participants will attend the laboratory at a pre-organised time. All participants will again be given a copy of the Information Sheet to read. They will then be verbally informed of the procedure by the researcher (Oral Consent Script, Appendix Three), and asked to thoroughly read the information sheet and informed consent form before signing. Participants will be given a copy of their signed consent form to keep and provided with an opportunity to ask any questions. Participants will then be randomly allocated to a truth telling or a lying group to provide their accounts. 
Truth tellers will be asked to recall a positive memorable event that occurred within the past two years, and we will provide the examples of going on holiday or having a celebratory birthday dinner (however, it will be clear that these are examples, and they are not limited to these options). They will be instructed to choose an event that they are comfortable writing about completely honestly and can remember in detail. Liars will be asked to invent a positive memorable event, and told that it should have occurred within the past two years. They will also be provided with the examples of going on holiday or having a celebratory birthday dinner. Both truth tellers and liars will be asked not to include any details in their account that could be used to identify them.
Data will be collected using Qualtrics. Participants will be asked to write either their truthful or deceptive first account of their memorable event as a response to an open-ended question, after which they will be presented with the HEXACO-60. After completing the HEXACO-60 personality questionnaire as a filler task, participants will be asked to think about the event they previously reported. A context reinstatement instruction will inform them to consider what sensory information they can recall, such as things they saw, could hear, or could smell. This instruction will encourage participants to remember the event, rather than just thinking about their previous account. After 30 seconds of the screen displaying this instruction, participants will be asked to again write another account about the same experience.
Once participants have provided two accounts regarding the same memorable event, they will then be asked to consider some other participants’ memorable events (i.e. the stimulus materials). The participant will be given a paper copy of two statements and asked to rate how consistent they believe the statements to be on a scale of 0% (highly inconsistent) to 100% (highly consistent). Ratings will be taken on a 0% - 100% scale to allow us to calculate an average “cut off” point, to differentiate how (in)consistent a statement needs to be to be considered (in)consistent based upon the comments on the stimulus materials. Once they have made their judgement, participants will then be asked to use a highlighter pen to notate a few key aspects of the statements that they consider to be (in)consistent, and add written notes to explain why they think that part is (in)consistent. Participants will be asked to do this for four pairs of statements, and then asked to write a brief statement explaining what they believe consistency is. These stimulus materials are taken from Hudson et al. (under review). This statement and the notes will be used in a thematic analysis to develop a clearer picture of how laypeople understand consistency and the LUCK scheme.
A pilot study will be run with 5 participants to test the methodology and ensure clarity within the instructions. It is anticipated that the study will take no more than 45 minutes.

Part Two
Materials: The thematic analysis conducted in Part One of the study will be used to inform a coding scheme based upon the layperson understanding of consistency (the Layperson Understanding of Consistency Key; LUCK). The LUCK scheme will tested for reliability using the memorable event accounts collected from the participants in Part One of the study by a team of independent coders.
Procedure: Six independent coders will be asked to categorise the 30 pairs of statements collected in Part One as either consistent or inconsistent using the LUCK scheme derived from Part One of the study. Coders will be blind to statement veracity and asked to make holistic decisions on whether a statement is consistent or inconsistent, based upon the LUCK scheme derived from Part One of the study. Coders will also be asked to code for the number of repetitions, reminiscences, omissions, and contradictions found within a statement. We will mathematically calculate whether a statement is consistent or inconsistent using the proportion of inconsistent details (i.e. omissions, reminiscence, and contradictions) to consistent details (i.e. repetitions).
registration_responses.q16.question:
Participants in Part One of the study will be randomly allocated to tell the truth or lie about a memorable event. They will also be provided with a random selection of four statement pairs (out of a bank of 16 statement pairs) to examine for between statement consistency. Participants will be randomly allocated to conditions by computer generation (i.e. the questionnaire used to collect the data will randomly allocate participants into conditions).

There is no manipulation in Part Two of the study.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Part One
Participants’ comments explaining which parts of the stimulus materials were (in)consistent will be examined in relation to their statement about what they believe consistency is (hereby referred to as “data”). Data will be analysed using a thematic analysis (Braun & Clark, 2006). First, we will familiarise ourselves with the data, by reading and re-reading the data, and identifying patterns that occur. Detailed notes will be taken to generate initial codes. From this we will make inferences about what the codes mean. Codes will then be combined into overarching themes to accurately represent the data, and we will establish how the themes support the data. Each theme will be clearly defined, and we will establish how each theme contributes to the holistic understanding of consistency. The themes will be reduced down to a clear and coherent set of LUCK coding instructions for Part Two of the study.
Part Two
To test the effectiveness of the LUCK scheme in comparison to the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme, a minimum of six independent coders will be asked to rate 30 pairs of accounts (collected in Part One of the study) as either consistent or inconsistent using the LUCK scheme and the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme. Interrater reliability of application of each coding scheme for each of the 30 pairs of statements will be calculated using Cohen’s kappa, to determine reliability of the scales. Reliability will be accepted at κ = .80. Following this, chi-squared analyses will determine whether rater classification of consistent/inconsistent significantly reflects the known veracity of the 30 pairs of statements for the LUCK scheme and the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme. There will be four cells for analysis: “truthful statements categorised as consistent”, “truthful statements categorised as inconsistent”, “deceptive statements categorised as consistent”, and “deceptive statements categorised as inconsistent”. To test whether the consistency heuristic correctly reflects statement veracity, we will collapse the four cells into two. We will combine the cell “truthful statements categorised as consistent” and “deceptive statements categorised as inconsistent”, which will represent the consistency heuristic. We will also combine the cells “truthful statements categorised as inconsistent” and “deceptive statements categorised as consistent”, which will reflect the repeat versus reconstruct hypothesis. We will seek to determine whether there is a significant difference between the number of statements that are correctly classified using the consistency heuristic coding scheme compared to the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme. Significance will be accepted at p < 05.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Part Two
To test the effectiveness of the LUCK scheme in comparison to the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme, a minimum of six independent coders will be asked to rate 30 pairs of accounts (collected in Part One of the study) as either consistent or inconsistent using the LUCK scheme and the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme. Interrater reliability of application of each coding scheme for each of the 30 pairs of statements will be calculated using Cohen’s kappa, to determine reliability of the scales. Reliability will be accepted at κ = .80. Following this, chi-squared analyses will determine whether rater classification of consistent/inconsistent significantly reflects the known veracity of the 30 pairs of statements for the LUCK scheme and the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme. There will be four cells for analysis: “truthful statements categorised as consistent”, “truthful statements categorised as inconsistent”, “deceptive statements categorised as consistent”, and “deceptive statements categorised as inconsistent”. To test whether the consistency heuristic correctly reflects statement veracity, we will collapse the four cells into two. We will combine the cell “truthful statements categorised as consistent” and “deceptive statements categorised as inconsistent”, which will represent the consistency heuristic. We will also combine the cells “truthful statements categorised as inconsistent” and “deceptive statements categorised as consistent”, which will reflect the repeat versus reconstruct hypothesis. We will seek to determine whether there is a significant difference between the number of statements that are correctly classified using the consistency heuristic coding scheme compared to the subcomponents of consistency coding scheme.

attributes.title: Emotion-Related Impulsivity: Testing A Model of Arousal Effects on Cognitive Control

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: Emotion-Related Impulsivity: Testing A Model of Arousal Effects on Cognitive Control

other.value: Diverse measures of psychopathology were collected as part of this study, and secondary analyses will consider how these dimensions of psychopathology relate to emotion-related impulsivity and/or arousal-induced decays in cognitive control

sample.value: The exact sample size will be determined by the available resources.  The target sample size is at least 50 subjects, with power analyses suggesting at least 107 (using G*Power).

analyses.value:
Linear regression models will be used to determine whether individual differences in emotion-related impulsivity (independent variable) relate to response inhibition (dependent variable). We hypothesize that greater emotion-related impulsivity will lead to poorer response inhibition.

Linear regression models will be used to determine whether individual differences in emotion-related impulsivity (independent variable) interact with arousal to predict post-stress response inhibition (dependent variable), controlling for baseline response inhibition. We hypothesize that greater emotion-related impulsivity will lead to poorer post-stress response inhibition, and that emotion-related impulsivity will interact with arousal such that greater arousal leads to poorer performance.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded if they do not obtain 50% accuracy on pro-saccade trials of the antisaccade task.

dependent.value: The dependent variable is response inhibition performance, as measured by the antisaccade task.

conditions.value: Participants completed a self-report measure of emotion-related impulsivity, a baseline measure of response inhibition, the antisaccade task, a well-validated stress induction procedure, the Trier Social Stress Test, and then a second measure of response inhibition using the antisaccade task. Psychophysiological indices of arousal were measured throughout study procedures.

hypothesis.value: The goal of the present study is to test whether individual differences in emotion-related impulsivity relate to arousal-induced effects on response inhibition performance.
