attributes.title: Replication of "Going Green to be Seen" at Universität Erfurt

q1.value: Conceptual replication of Griscevicius´ "Going green to be seen" experiment 1

q3.value:
This replication is conducted as a part of a master´s psychology seminar at Uni Erfurt. 

The purpose is to replicate the effect found in Griscevicius (2010) paper named "Going Green to be seen". This project aims to conceptually replicate only experiment Nr. 1, which is about the effect of status motives on a purchase decision where participants have to decide betweeen the sustainable and the conventional option of the same kind of product (3 decisions).  

In contrast to the original study, this replication takes part as an online survey using the platform "soscisurvey.de".

q4.value:
The following hypotheses 1-4 are the same ones predicted in the original study by Griscevicius (2010). Hypothesis 5 is newly added here to control for "perceived coolness of buying green" as another potential reason for choosing the sustainable option.

General hypothesis: When status motives are activated (experimental group), significantly more people will choose the environmental option compared to no activation of status motives (control group). 

Hypothesis 1: 

Significantly more people decide for the sustainable car in EG than CG. (alternative hypothesis).

The percentage of people deciding for the sustainable car in EG compared to CG is not significantly different. (null hypothesis)

Hypothesis 2: Significantly more people decide for the sustainable household cleaner in EG than CG. (alternative hypothesis)

The percentage of people deciding for the sustainable household cleaner in EG compared to CG is not significantly different. (null hypothesis)

Hypothesis 3: Significantly more people decide for the sustainable dishwasher in EG than CG. (alternative hypothesis)

The percentage of people deciding for the sustainable dishwasher in EG compared to CG is not significantly different. (null hypothesis)

To-be-relicated hypothesis 4: There is a significant effect of status (EG) on the product composite (three product decisions combined).  (non-directional) (alternative hypothesis)

There is no significant effect of status on the product composite. (null hypothesis)

Hypothesis 5: The relationship between status motives and a green purchase decision is influenced by the perceived coolness of buying green (non-directional). (alternative hypothesis)

The relationship between status motives and a green purchase decision is not significantly influenced by the perceived coolness of buying green. (null hypothesis)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (motive induction: short story reading) and 2 levels (status story, control story).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through spreading and posting the study-link online, in social networks and groups of degree programms mainly from University of Erfurt. There is no payment, so the participation is completely voluntarily. Everyone can take part if they are at least 18 years old.

q13.value: The target sample size for this study is 130 participants (Original study: N=168). I will attempt to recruit up to 130, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q14.value: The program G*Power was used for power analysis. An analysis with a pursued power of 0.8, alpha 0.05 and an initial effect size of d=0.47 (found in the original study) revealed that 114 pariticipants are needed to reach this power.

q15.value: Data collection is stopped when N = 130 is reached or when the data collection time is over (08.02.20 - 28.02.20).

question.value:
Two different motives will be manipulated by the participants reading a short story before deciding for products. 
The experimental group will read a short story which elicits a social status motive, the control group reads a short story which doesn´t elicit any motives.

The measured variable is the frequency of a pro-environmental decision (hypotheses 1-3) or rather the product composite (hypothesis 4) originated through the three decisions. 

The decisions are forced- choice and there are two options for every product of the 3: sustainable or conventional product. 

Additionaly, the perceived coolness of green purchases is measured by two items ("Magst du es, deine Käufe umweltbewusst zu tätigen?" & "Findest du es cool, nachhaltig einzukaufen?"). The scale used for both is a 5-point Likert Scale from 1 ("strongly disagree) to 5 ("strongly agree").

The coolness items were not a part of the original study but they were added in this conceptual replication to control for this construct (confounded variable).
I will take the mean of the two coolness-questions above to create a single measure of "perceived coolness of green purchases".

For hypothesis 1-3, I will use a Chi-Square test to conduct 3 single tests for each product (car, cleaner, dishwasher) which analyzes if there is a significant difference between the percentage of people deciding for the green product in experimental group versus the percentage deciding for the green product in control group. This test is repeated for every product.

For hypothesis 4, I will use a t-test for independent groups with one between-subjects factor (motive induction). The dependent variable for the t-test is the product composite decided for. (To-be-replicated effect)

The testing of hypothesis 5 is part of the t-test for independent groups (hypothesis 4) where "perceived coolness of buying green" is included as a potential confounding variable.

The statistical models are the same used in the original study exept for controlling for "perceived coolness of buying green". 

The statistical analysis might be partly changed if erros in the analysis procedure happen due to the fact that this is a practice project in a university course.

q21.value: I will use a standard  p<.05 criteria for determining if the t-test and also the chi-square-tests suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: To be included, participants have to answer to all of the questions expect of gender if they don´t want to.

q23.value: If a participant doesn´t complete all of the three purchase decisions and the two questions concerning perceived coolness of buying green, they will be excluded.

attributes.title: The effects of foods that promote nitric-oxide synthesis on endurance exercise performance: a systematic review of randomised controlled trials

q1.value: The effects of foods that promote nitric-oxide synthesis on endurance exercise performance: a systematic review of randomised controlled trials

q2.value: Noah D'Unienville, Jonathan Buckley, Alison Coates, Alison M Hill, Maximillian J Nelson, Henry Blake

q3.value: Nitric oxide (NO) is a gaseous signalling molecule that is NO mediates a number of physiological actions including skeletal muscle contractile properties, endothelial function, mitochondrial biogenesis and respiration, muscle repair and antioxidant defences. Through its modulation of these systems, increasing NO synthesis by thought to induce a number of effects that may enhance endurance exercise performance. As the level of NO synthesis can be influenced by nitrate, nitrite, L-arginine, L-Citrulline and polyphenols, this systematic review will evaluate whether increasing dietary intake of foods that are rich in these components may improve endurance performance.

q4.value: If foods are rich in compounds that can improve nitric oxide synthesis, they will improve endurance performance.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
There will be no date restriction on the search strategy and studies must be peer-reviewed and written in English.
The search will be conducted in Medline, EMBASE, Scopus, SPORTDiscus and Web of Science and will use both MeSH headings and keywords. Only randomised controlled trials will be included.
Noah d’Unienville was be responsible for drafting of the search strategy, which was refined in accordance with the supervisory team and an academic librarian specialising in systematic reviews. Once finalised, the search was conducted independently by two reviewers using Covidence.
The search terms in the attached Systematic Review Food Search Table will be adapted to each database search with the ‘OR’ function being applied to all terms within each column, while the ‘AND’ function will be applied between each column. Where possible, database searches will be limited to human studies, and thus population search terms will be omitted. ‘Intervention’ search terms include compounds that increase nitric oxide synthesis, as well as notable foods that are rich in these compounds.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: Title and abstract screening in Covidence has been completed.

question.value:
Inclusion criteria: intervention
Interventions must increase dietary intake of compounds that promote nitric oxide synthesis. Such compounds include polyphenols, nitrite, nitrate, L-citrulline and L-arginine. Interventions must increase intake of these compounds only via consumption of whole foods, juices, concentrates or plant extracts and studies must explicitly state the food source(s) of these compounds. These foods cannot be consumed in combination with other foods/supplements that may influence performance (e.g. caffeine) unless the comparator group also contains these components. Where applicable, foods should also be evaluated against equivalent comparators (e.g. chocolate milk vs non-chocolate milk rather than vs a sports-electrolyte drink) and not be dissimilar in energy content and macronutrient profile. 

Inclusion criteria: performance
To be eligible for inclusion, studies must report an external measure of locomotor performance in a test with a duration of greater than two minutes. Intermittent-type endurance performance tests must have a work duration of greater than two minutes and cannot have between-repetition recovery intervals of >60 secs. Performance tests must also be conducted in normobaric, normoxic and temperate conditions. Marathon performance will not be considered as eligible within this review due to its lack of controlled conditions. Further, studies will be ineligible where performance is only measured as an indicator of recovery (e.g. hours or days following an exercise stimulus designed to induce damage/stress) rather than being assessed at maximum capacity or following a standarised preload.  

Noah d’Unienville conducted the search strategy in each of the listed databases. Citation & abstracts will be exported to Endnote, where duplicates were removed. Results were then exported to Covidence, where study title and abstracts were screened, before full text reviews will be conducted on relevant studies. Reasons for exclusion of full-texts will be: ineligible measure of endurance performance, ineligible test conditions, co-supplementation (with other foods/compounds), pharmaceutical (not food-derived) supplementation, animal study, paediatric population, geriatric population, non-English language, not peer-reviewed or other (will be specified). Disagreements regarding eligibility between the two researchers will be settled by consultation with a third researcher. If no full text is available, they will be sought from the authors. Reference lists will also be assessed to identify additional relevant studies. A PRISMA flow diagram will be used to illustrate the number results from the search strategy and reference list pearling, articles included/excluded during screening process, studies excluded after full text review, full-text articles eligible for qualitative synthesis and full-text articles eligible for meta-analysis. Noah d’Unienville will draft a data extraction form to ensure that extracted data is consistent with the questions of this review, and this form will be piloted on two included studies by two researchers independently.
Not applicable.
Not applicable. The variables that will be used to make inferences are included in the statistical analysis plan below.

Data from included studies will be qualitatively synthesised. Depending on the heterogeneity of study designs, populations, supplementation and performance tests used, a meta-analysis may be conducted, with heterogeneity assessed using the I² statistic.

attributes.title: Empathic Anger and Altruistic Helping and Punishment
attributes.description: A set of studies examining how personal and empathic anger predict egoistic and altruistic interpersonal behavior.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: This project is a pre-registration of my dissertation. All study methods and hypotheses have been reviewed and approved by the Virginia Commonwealth University IRB.

dataCollectionDates.value: Project began January 2019, expected end date is April 2020.

question2a.value:
Study 1: 
1. Anger experimental condition: two conditions (empathic anger, personal anger), between-subjects, orthogonal
2. State empathic responding (Batson Empathic Adjectives Scale and State Empathic Anger Scale) (orthogonal)


Study 2: 
1. Anger experimental condition: two conditions (empathic anger, personal anger), between-subjects, orthogonal
2. Decision cost experimental condition: two conditions (high cost, low cost), between-subjects, orthogonal, measured as main effect and moderator

question2b.value:
1. Task reallocation operationalized as third-party compensation (reallocating task to reduce workload for third partner), third-party punishment (reallocating task to increase workload for the leader who originally allocated the task), self-compensation (reallocating task to reduce workload for self), and escape from the situation (choosing not to make any decision).

2. Motivational goals to engage in interpersonal decisions was measured using the Decisional Goals Questionnaire

question3b.value:
1. Trait variables: 
a.   Five-factor trait curiosity (Kashdan et al., 2018). Social curiosity is the main dimension of curiosity predicted to influence empathy and interpersonal behavior, but all other facets will be tested as well.
b.   Mindful attention and awareness (Brown & Ryan, 2003). 

2. Decision cost experimental condition: two conditions (high cost, low cost), between-subjects, orthogonal, measured as moderator

3. Trait variables assessed as screening variables and covariates - I will assess for univariate and multivariate outliers for these variables, and will test our hypotheses both with and without these variables. Our main predictions will be tested without these covariates, and as a secondary follow-up test we will assess hypothesis tests with these covariates added as controls. Covariate traits include:
a. Dispositional aggression measured by the Brief Aggression Questionnaire (Webster et al., 2015). 
b. Need to belong measured by the Need to Belong Scale (Leary, Kelly, Cottrell, & Schreindorfer, 2013). 
c. Sadistic impulses will be measured by the Short Sadistic Impulse Scale (SSIS, O’Meara et al., 2011). 
d. Dispositional empathic anger measured by the Trait Empathic Anger Scale (TEAS; Vitaglione & Barnett, 2003).
e. Trait empathy will be measured by the Questionnaire Measure for Cognitive and Affective Empathy (Reniers et al., 2011). 

4. State variables used for screening - I will control for baselines positive and negative affect in all analyses. Positive and negative affect will be measured using the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988), as well as post-task positive emotion measured by the Discrete Emotions Questionnaire (Harmon-Jones et al., 2016).

question10b.value:
*STUDY 1*

Purpose:
Study 1 will build on prior research by directly comparing personal anger and empathic anger on motivation to self-compensate, escape a retaliation situation, help a third party, or punish an offender. Only a few studies have directly compared these two states within a single experiment (David et al., 2017; FeldmanHall et al., 2015; Gummerum et al., 2016; Omara et al., 2011), but none of these offered self-compensation and escape together as behavioral options in response to unfairness. Additionally, no studies of empathic anger have directly measured self-focused and other-focused goals as mediators of anger effects on behavioral decisions. Study 1 will also constrain participants to choose one behavioral response (either helping, punishment, self-compensation, or escape) so as to conceptually replicate findings that individuals are more likely to choose self-compensation than punishment when they are personally angered by an offender (FeldmanHall et al., 2015), but are more likely to compensate a victim or punish an offender when a third party is treated unfairly (Gummerum et al., 2016; van Prooijen, 2010).

Design and Participants:
Study 1 will have two conditions: Empathic Anger and Personal Anger. Based on a pilot study's finding that personal and empathic anger predict different levels of prosocial activity motivation at d = .46, we conducted a power analysis to determine the number of participants needed to detect this effect size  within a moderation analysis (which would involve measuring 2 factors and an interaction). A power analysis in G*Power indicated that 151 participants would be needed to detect an interaction effect size of d = .46 between two groups and a continuous factor with 80% power and α = .05. Based on this power analysis, study 1 will recruit a minimum of 200 adult participants recruited through MTurk, who will be compensated $1.00 each. 

Measures and Procedure:
Participants will complete the study through an electronic questionnaire system (Qualtrics) which will present study tasks and information. After indicating their informed consent, they will first read the instructions for the MTPP (see below for full description) and respond to a short quiz indicating they understand the instructions. Participants will enter their name, and both they and the other participants will be referred to by name (rather than “third player”, etc.). Participants will then complete the following measures/tasks:

Baseline Positive and Negative Affect. To control for individual differences in positive and negative affect entering the study, participants will first respond to the short form of the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988). Participants report how strongly they feel emotions with positive valence (e.g., “Alert”) and negative valence (e.g., “Afraid”) on a 1 (Not at all) to 5 (Extremely) scale.

Moderator Variables: Participants will complete two trait variable questionnaires, including:
 
a. Mindful Attention and Awareness Scale. Participants' trait mindfulness will be measured by the MAAS (Brown & Ryan, 2003). The scale is listed on a 1 (almost always) to 6 (almost never) scale with questions asking about tendencies to act mindlessly (e.g., "I could be experiencing some emotion and not be conscious of it until some time later").

b. Five-Factor Trait Curiosity (Kashdan et al., 2018). Lastly participants will complete a trait measure of curiosity, the five-factor curiosity scale. Participants respond to questions about their curiosity habits (e.g., "I like to learn about the habits of others") on a 1 (Does not describe me at all) to 7 (Describes me completely) scale.

Anger Condition and Modified Third-Party Punishment Task. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive the Personal Anger or Empathic Anger condition and will complete the MTPP task. In the prototypical Third-Party Punishment task (Fehr & Fishbacher, 2003), participants witness a "dictator" participant allocate unfair amounts of money to a "recipient" participant. This unfair allocation has been shown to elicit personal anger when the participant is the recipient, and empathic anger when the participant is a third-party witness to the allocation decision (Fehr & Fishbacher, 2003). In the MTPP, the same type of allocation paradigm is used but task assignments, rather than money, are allocated. This modified task will allow us to examine how reactions to unfairness generalize beyond monetary decisions.

In the MTPP, participants are given a cover story that the study is researching group behavior, specifically “how groups of people task delegation decisions in groups online vs. in-person.” The participant will ostensibly be paired with two other partners online through a university research server. In actuality, the participant is the only player, and the two partners are computerized.

Participants will read that the first part of the study will involve the group members choosing how to delegate a set of tasks. The tasks involve rating and describing three sets of pictures which have been shown to elicit minimal affective responses (e.g., a floppy disc or lamp). There are to be two rounds of photos to describe in the study. One of the participants will be randomly assigned to choose how many photos each group member must complete (the group leader). Participants then rate and describe one example photo, and then will respond to attention check questions to indicate they understand the point of the study.

The computer player "Alex" is chosen to be the delegator for the photo tasks. Participants are shown the following allocations based on their experimental condition fr Round 1 (object photos).

- Personal Anger: Total number of photos is 15. Participant is assigned 10 photos to describe; second group member is assigned 5 photos to describe; group leader assigns him/herself 0 photos.

- Empathic Anger: Total number of photos is 30. Participant is assigned 10 photos to describe; second group member is assigned 20 photos to describe; group leader assigns him/herself 0 photos.

Participants then have the opportunity to write a public message to the other participants. Because the players are all computerized, the participant will see predetermined answers, with their own comment added to make it look like all players have posted messages to each other. On the next page, all of the players' messages are posted.

Next, participants will actually complete the photo description assignment, and will rate and describe 10 photos (descriptions must be 100 characters at least). After completing this assignment, participants will either see a waiting screen making them wait for a few seconds while the other players complete the task (if in the empathic anger condition), or they will immediately move to the next part of the group study.

Empathy and State Affect. After Round 1 of the MTPP task and after seeing the allocation choice for Round 2, participants will report their empathic and personal anger, empathic concern, personal distress, and positive affect immediately before making the Round 2 reallocation decision. All emotions will be rated from 1 (Not at all) to 7 (Extremely).

Empathic Anger. The State Empathic Anger Scale (SEAS; Vitaglione & Barnett, 2003) measures anger felt on behalf of another person. including eight emotional adjectives (mad, angry, furious, resentful, irritated, enraged, aggravated, outraged).

Empathic Concern and Distress. Empathic concern and distress will be measured through Batson’s Emotional Adjective Scale (BEAS; Batson, Fultz, & Schoenrade, 1987), consisting of 14 emotional adjectives measuring other-oriented concern (sympathetic, warm, softhearted, moved, compassionate, tender) and self-focused personal distress (troubled, upset, worried, disturbed, grieved, alarmed, perturbed, distressed).

Positive Affect. Positive affect will be measured with the Happiness and Relaxation subscales of the Discrete Emotions Questionnaire (Harmon-Jones et al., 2016).

On the next page, participants will be told the group leader will choose the next task allocation, which will be completed at the end of the study. They are told there are now 40 photos to be completed, and both the participant and the other group member have been assigned 20 of the 40 photos. The group leader (Alex) assigns themselves 0.

After seeing the Round 2 allocation, participants report their state empathy and affect once more. Next, participants are also then told that they have been selected as the moderator for Round 2 of the study. Participants then choose whether they want to reallocate photos for themselves, the group leader, or the partner participant. Once they make this decision, they then choose how many photos to reallocate (0 - 20). Later, participants will learn that they do not in fact need to complete this final rating/description task.

Reallocation Decision. In Round 2, participants will have the option to reallocate photos for themselves (self-compensation), the third player (third party helping), or the group leader (punishment). They also have the option of not changing any photos (Escape).

Decisional Goals. To assess participants’ goals when choosing their helping/punishment/escape decision, participants will complete the Goals Following Interpersonal Transgressions scale (GFIT; Rasmussen & Boon, 2017). The full scale measures 12 dimensions of behavioral motivation following an interpersonal transgression. For the current study, only the Power, Moral, Reputation, Protect Others, Self-Protect, Emotional Well-Being, Justice, and Education subscales will be included. Participants rate on a 1 (not at all strongly) to 7 (very strongly) scale the extent to which they held each goal in making their decision. In analyses, the Power, Reputation, Self-Protect, Avoiding Conflict, and Emotional Well-Being dimensions will be assessed as self-focused goals, and the Moral, Protect Others, Justice, Education, and Forgiveness subscales will be assessed as other-focused goals.

Post-Decision Affect. Participants will be asked to report their state affect once more using the Discrete Emotions Questionnaire in order to assess whether helping or punishment decisions positively influenced participants’ mood.

Trait Measures. Finally, participants will complete a questionnaire including a number of trait measures. These measures will be assessed after the primary measures of interest so as to not prime participants with concepts of anger or empathy.

Trait Empathic Anger. Trait empathic anger is the extent to which participants tend to feel empathic anger in their daily lives, and will be measured using the Trait Empathic Anger Scale (TEAS; Vitaglione & Barnett, 2003), a seven-item Likert-scale ranging from 1 (Does Not Describe Me Very Well) to 5 (Describes Me Very Well); e.g. “I feel angry for other people when they have been victimized by others.”

Trait Anger and Aggression. The dispositional tendency to get angry across different situations will be measured with the Brief Aggression Questionnaire (Webster et al., 2015). This measure asks participants to report how they would describe themselves on a 1 (Does not describe me at all) to 5 (Describes me very well) scale, (e.g., “Given enough provocation, I may hit another person”).

Need to Belong. The dispositional need to belong and feel social support will be measured by the Need to Belong Scale (Leary, Kelly, Cottrell, & Schreindorfer, 2013). This asks participants to report on a 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree) scale to what extent they generally are distressed by social exclusion or desire social connection (e.g., “If other people don't seem to accept me, I don't let it bother me”).

Sadistic Impulses. Participants' tendencies to want to hurt others in everyday life will be measured by the Short Sadistic Impulse Scale (SSIS, O’Meara et al., 2011). The scale is listed on a 1 (Strongly disagree) to 7 (Strongly agree) scale (e.g., “Hurting people would be exciting”).

Final Description: Participants are finally informed that they will not be asked to complete the Round 2 rating assignment. They will then be asked to complete their demographics and a final short cooldown task before finishing the study.

Demographics. Participants’ gender, race, and age will be self-reported.

Cooldown task: Participants will be asked to complete the same emotional cooldown task described in Study 3 in order to mitigate the psychological effects of having been induced to feel anger.

End-of-study Mood. To determine whether participants are leaving the study in a positive or neutral emotional state, they will lastly be asked to complete a short mood questionnaire. This measure will be used only to monitor participants' responses, and thus will only include only 1 item in order to minimize participant frustration given the high quantity of affective self-report questionnaires in the study. The item will ask "Overall, how positive or negative is your mood right now?" and will utilize a sliding scale ranging from -100 ('Extremely negative; the worst I've felt in a long time') to 100 ('Extremely positive; the best I've felt in a long time') with a midpoint of 0 ('Completely neutral; neither positive or negative').

Afterward, participants will be fully debriefed with a written letter explaining the purpose of the study and the deception elements.



*STUDY 2*
Study 2 will again compare the effects of personal and empathic anger on motivation to help, punish, or self-compensate while additionally assessing the effect of high or low personal cost through adding a “payment” aspect to participant decisions. High-cost payments will consist of SONA credits whereas low-cost payments will consist of raffle ticket entries for a separate prize above and beyond SONA credit compensation. SONA credits are expected to be perceived as more valuable as participants (undergraduate students enrolled in Introduction to Psychology) must obtain a certain number of credits in order to pass their Introduction to Psychology class. If empathic anger predicts similar levels of helping, punishment, and other-focused goals in the high and low-cost conditions, this will be more direct evidence of altruism than what has been posited in past literature.

Study 2 includes the same hypotheses as Study 1 as well as a moderation hypothesis:

H6. Decision cost will interact with experimental condition to predict participants' decision to self-compensate, helping, and punishment decisions, such that:
a.   Across all conditions, participants will be more likely to self-compensate in the high cost condition compared to the low cost condition.
b.   The difference between decision outcomes in the high and low cost conditions will be stronger in the personal anger condition than the empathic anger condition. 

Method
Design: Study 2 will have a 2 (Empathic vs. Personal Anger) x 2 (High vs. Low Cost) factorial design. Using the same d = .46 effect size as Study 1, a power analysis indicated that 211participants would be adequate to detect main and interaction effect sizes of similar magnitude with 80% power and α = .05 using ANCOVA (controlling for time of semester and baseline affect).

Participants: Participants in Study 2 will be either undergraduate students at VCU participating for course credit (1 SONA credit) and entered to win a raffle for several gift cards.

Procedure. Participants will complete the study in groups of three or more in a computer lab setting at Virginia Commonwealth University for 1 SONA credit (or will complete the study online through the MTurk website at www.mturk.com). After informed consent they will complete the following measures and tasks.

Baseline Positive and Negative Affect. Participants will first complete the PANAS as a measure of baseline positive and negative affect.

Moderator Variables: Participants will complete the Mindful Attention and Awareness Scale and the Five-Factor Trait Curiosity Scale.

Modified Third-Party Punishment Game. Participants will first read the instructions for the MTPP as described in Study 1, and will respond to a short quiz indicating they understand the instructions. Participants will then enter their name, and both they and the other participants will be referred to by name (rather than “third player” or group leader). They will then be randomly assigned to the Personal Anger or Empathic Anger condition of the study, and will complete the MTPP as described in Study 1.

Once participants have been brought to the Round 2 reallocation task, they will be randomly assigned to the High Cost or Low Cost condition. Unlike Study 1 where participants could choose how to reallocate the photos freely, now participants must "pay" to reallocate photo tasks.

High Cost Condition. In the high-cost condition, participants will have to "pay" for photo reallocation with SONA credit or from their MTurk compensation. They will be instructed that they can pay up to .05 SONA credits or $0.05 from their final compensation amount in order to reallocate photos in each round, with .05 credits/dollars per photo. The amount of credit they pay to reallocate will ostensibly be taken from their final credit amount. (In actuality, participants will receive their full credit amount at the end of the study).

Low Cost Condition. In the low-cost condition, participants will have to pay for photo reallocation with entries to the gift card raffle. They will be told that each participant receives 20 raffle ticket entries, and they can pay between 0 and 20 entries to reallocate photos, with one raffle entry being equal to one photo reallocations. The number of raffle entries they pay will ostensibly be taken from their final compensation amount. (In actuality, participants will receive the full number of entries at the end of the study).

Decisional Goals. To assess participants’ goals when choosing their helping/punishment/escape decision, participants will complete the Goals Following Interpersonal Transgressions scale (GFIT; Rasmussen & Boon, 2017). The full scale measures 12 dimensions of behavioral motivation following an interpersonal transgression. For the current study, only the Power, Moral, Reputation, Protect Others, Self-Protect, Emotional Well-Being, Justice, and Education subscales will be included. Participants rate on a 1 (not at all strongly) to 7 (very strongly) scale the extent to which they held each goal in making their decision. In analyses, the Power, Reputation, Self-Protect, Avoiding Conflict, and Emotional Well-Being dimensions will be assessed as self-focused goals, and the Moral, Protect Others, Justice, Education, and Forgiveness subscales will be assessed as other-focused goals.

Post-Decision Affect. Participants will be asked to report their state affect once more using the Discrete Emotions Questionnaire in order to assess whether helping or punishment decisions positively influenced participants’ mood.

Manipulation Check. Participants will respond to three manipulation check questions to determine that the two anger conditions are perceived to be equally unfair, and that the high-cost payment tokens (SONA credits) are perceived to be more important than the low-cost payment tokens (raffle ticket entries).
1) How fair did you think the photo rating task allocation was? (1 = completely unfair, 7 = completely fair)
2) How important was it to you that you got the maximum number of SONA credits [raffle entries] as you could? (1 = not at all important, 7 = extremely important).
3) Have you ever completed a task similar to the photo rating task in other studies or as part of a class?

Trait Measures. Finally, participants will complete a questionnaire including a number of trait measures. These measures will be assessed after the primary measures of interest so as to not prime participants with concepts of anger or empathy.

Trait Empathic Anger. Trait empathic anger is the extent to which participants tend to feel empathic anger in their daily lives, and will be measured using the Trait Empathic Anger Scale (TEAS; Vitaglione & Barnett, 2003), a seven-item Likert-scale ranging from 1 (Does Not Describe Me Very Well) to 5 (Describes Me Very Well); e.g. “I feel angry for other people when they have been victimized by others.”

Trait Anger and Aggression. The dispositional tendency to get angry across different situations will be measured with the Brief Aggression Questionnaire (Webster et al., 2015). This measure asks participants to report how they would describe themselves on a 1 (Does not describe me at all) to 5 (Describes me very well) scale, (e.g., “Given enough provocation, I may hit another person”).

Need to Belong. The dispositional need to belong and feel social support will be measured by the Need to Belong Scale (Leary, Kelly, Cottrell, & Schreindorfer, 2013). This asks participants to report on a 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree) scale to what extent they generally are distressed by social exclusion or desire social connection (e.g., “If other people don't seem to accept me, I don't let it bother me”).

Sadistic Impulses. Participants' tendencies to want to hurt others in everyday life will be measured by the Short Sadistic Impulse Scale (SSIS, O’Meara et al., 2011). The scale is listed on a 1 (Strongly disagree) to 7 (Strongly agree) scale (e.g., “Hurting people would be exciting”).

Final Description: Participants are finally informed that they will not be asked to complete the Round 2 rating assignment. They will then be asked to complete their demographics and a final short cooldown task before finishing the study.

Demographics. Participants’ gender, race, and age will be self-reported.

Cooldown task: Participants will be asked to complete the same emotional cooldown task described in Study 3 in order to mitigate the psychological effects of having been induced to feel anger.

End-of-study Mood. To determine whether participants are leaving the study in a positive or neutral emotional state, they will lastly be asked to complete a short mood questionnaire. This measure will be used only to monitor participants' responses, and thus will only include only 1 item in order to minimize participant frustration given the high quantity of affective self-report questionnaires in the study. The item will ask "Overall, how positive or negative is your mood right now?" and will utilize a sliding scale ranging from -100 ('Extremely negative; the worst I've felt in a long time') to 100 ('Extremely positive; the best I've felt in a long time') with a midpoint of 0 ('Completely neutral; neither positive or negative').

Debriefing: Participants will be debriefed about the true purpose of the study, and will be told that they will receive the full compensation amount regardless of how many photos they reallocated in the study.

question4b.value: Participants will volunteer to be a part of the study. Participants younger than 18 or who have completed a study with similar measures are excluded from participating. Participants who express suspicion about the deceptive elements of the study will be screened from final analyses.

question5b.value:
Study 1: Participants will be adults aged 18 or older from the US participating on Amazon MTurk.

Study 2: Participants will be college students aged 18 or older participating for course credit.

question6b.value:
Study 1 will have two conditions (Empathic Anger and Personal Anger). Drawing from a pilot test finding that personal and empathic anger predict different levels of prosocial activity motivation at d = .46, a power analysis indicated that 150 participants would be adequate to detect a similar main effect and interactions of a similar effect size (i.e., the difference between two independent samples) with 80% power and α = .05. Study 1 will recruit a minimum of 150 adult participants recruited through MTurk. 

Study 2 will have a 2 (Empathic vs. Personal Anger) x 2 (High vs. Low Cost) factorial design. Using the same d = .23 effect size as Study 1, a power analysis indicated that 211 participants would be adequate to detect main or interaction effect sizes of similar magnitude with 80% power and α = .05 using ANCOVA (controlling for time of semester and baseline affect). Because the effect size of interest may be smaller, we will continue to collect participants past this minimum in order to increase power.

question7b.value:
S1: Data collection will be terminated once 300 MTurk participants have participated.  If participants must be removed from analyses due to suspicion and this reduced the sample below that required by the power analysis, data collection will resume until the minimum required by the power analysis is achieved with non-suspicious participants.

S2: Data collection will be terminated on March 1, 2020, or once the minimum number of participants indicated by the power analysis has been collected.  If participants must be removed from analyses due to suspicion and this reduced the sample below that required by the power analysis, data collection will resume until this minimum is achieved with non-suspicious participants.

question8b.value:
Participants will be excluded from analyses for the following reasons:
- If participants miss two or more attention check questions
- If participants fail an additional suspicion probe and indicate they did not believe the experimental manipulation
- If there is evidence to suggest participants are bots (e.g., suspicious answers, repeated geographical coordinates outside the US as described by Bai (2018) (see https://www.maxhuibai.com/blog/evidence-that-responses-from-repeating-gps-are-random)
- Evidence suggests participants were not paying attention (a final question asking participants about their work quality, overly consistent reponses)

question9b.value:
We will assess data collection each day, and every 25-30 participants, we will check the final mood check item (and no other data). The final mood check scale ranges from -100 to +100, and we will assess whether more than 5% of participants are reporting their final mood as being -75 on this scale or lower (as low as -100). If more than 5% of participants report extremely low mood in this manner, the project team will stop data collection and reconvene with the IRB with an amended protocol in order to ensure participant psychological risks are minimized.

If more than 50% of participants are excluded due to suspicion or other issues, we will pause data collection and restart the study with amended recruitment and potentially amended data collection procedures.

question6c.value: We will use holm-bonferroni adjustments (sequential alpha adjustment) to address multiple hypothesis tests for the 8 possible goal mediators.

question7c.value: Pairwise deletion will be used when possible to maximize statistical power. Data will not be interpolated.

question8c.value: Items with low tem-total correlations (lower than .15) will be excluded from follow-up hypothesis tests to assess whether the item influences the result.

question9c.value: Log transformations may be applied to the task reallocation outcome, as it is a count variable with high expected zero frequencies. However we will also employ zero-inflated poisson regression techniques if these outcome distributions are found to violate assumptions of OLS regression.

question10c.value: Main analyses will be conducted using OLS regression. If these assumptions are violated we will first attempt to apply a linear transformation, and then utilize non parametric techniques, if the assumptions are not met with a linear transformation (e.g., log-transforming the interpersonal decision count variable).

question1a.value:
H1. Experiencing empathic anger and personal anger will predict different interpersonal responses to either personally-experienced unfairness (personal anger condition) or witnessing third-party unfairness (empathic anger condition), such that:
a.	Empathic anger will predict more willingness to help a victim of unfairness than personal anger.
b.	Personal anger will predict more willingness to punish a perpetrator of unfairness than empathic anger.
c.	Personal anger will predict more self-compensation than empathic anger. 

H2. Experiencing empathic anger and personal anger will be associated with different goal tendencies, such that:
a.	Empathic anger will evoke stronger other-oriented (altruistic) motivational goals.
b.	Personal anger will evoke stronger self-oriented (egoistic) motivational goals.

H3. The effects of empathic and personal anger on interpersonal decisions in response to unfairness will be mediated by goal type, such that:
a.	The effect of anger condition on differences in helping decisions will be mediated by salience of other-oriented goals.
b.	The effect of anger condition on differences in punishment decisions will be mediated by salience of self-oriented goals.
c.	The effect of anger condition on differences in self-compensation will be mediated by salience of self-focused goals. 

H4. High decision cost will decrease willingness to help a victim of unfairness and punish a perpetrator of unfairness across both personal anger and empathic anger conditions.

question2a.value:
No specific hypotheses for interactions are hypothesized, however these studies will investigate seven research questions related to the interaction effects of decision cost and hypoegoic traits:

1a) How might decision cost moderate the effects of personal or empathic anger on interpersonal decisions to help a victim of unfairness, punish a perpetrator of unfairness, self-compensate, or escape the situation?
1b) How might decision cost moderate the effects of personal or empathic anger on self and other-oriented motivation?

2a) How might trait-level differences in hypoegoic cognitive states (specifically trait mindfulness and trait curiosity) relate to interpersonal decisions?
2b) How might hypoegoic traits moderate the effects of personal or empathic anger on interpersonal decisions?
2c) How might hypoegoic traits moderate the effects of personal or empathic anger on self and other-oriented motivation?
2d) How might hypoegoic traits moderate the effects of decision cost on interpersonal decisions?
2e) How might hypoegoic traits moderate the effects of decision cost on self and other-oriented motivation?

question3a.value:
Participants will be asked to report several manipulation check variables:

1) To measure differences between empathic anger and personal anger, participants will report the extent to which they perceive the job allocation to be fair to themselves, the task delegator, and the third group member. We predict in the empathic anger condition, participants will report feeling the task is most unfair to the third group member. In the personal anger condition, participants will report feeling the task is most unfair to themselves.

2) The high and low cost conditions will differ by what participants are asked to "pay" in order to reallocate job task assignments. In the high cost condition participants must reallocate class credit points; in the low cost condition participants must reallocate raffle tickets. To measure differences in the high and low decision cost conditions, participants will be asked at the end of the study the extent to which it was important for them to receive each type of compensation (raffle tickets and course credits). Participants in all conditions are expected to report it is more important for them receive class credit points than raffle tickets.

question5a.value: These hypotheses are drawn from research on the role of egoic and hypoegoic attentional focus in prosocial responses (e.g., Berry, Cairo, et al., 2018), the empathy-altruism hypothesis (Batson et al., 1988; 2015), and research on the third-party punishment and empathy (e.g., Pedersen, McAuliffe, & McCullough, 2018).

question1c.value:
Variables: 

1. Personal/empathic anger experimental condition (dummy coded with personal anger = 0)

2. State empathic responding measured as composite scores of the Batson Empathic Adjectives Scale and State Empathic Anger Scale

3. Decisional goals, measured by the Goals Following Interpersonal Transgressions Scale (GFIT, Rasmussen & Boone, 2018). Each goal will be calculated as a composite goal type based on the original scale paper. Additionally, a latent variable of "self-focused goals" and "other focused goals" will be computed, in which the Power, Reputation, Self-Protect, Avoiding Conflict, and Emotional Well-Being dimensions will be assessed as self-focused goals, and the Moral, Protect Others, Justice,  Education, and Forgiveness subscales will be assessed as other-focused goals. 

4. Interpersonal decisions, measured as whether participants choose to reallocate task assignments for themselves (self-compensation), a third party (third party compensation), the offender (punishment) or no one (escape). Measured as a score from 0-20 for intensity of reallocation, and also as a category (type of help).

question2c.value:
Hayes' PROCESS macro will be used to estimate the bootstrapped indirect effect of experimental condition on interpersonal decisions through the mediator of decisional goals (each goal type separately). Additionally a structural equation model will be computed to assess the mediational effect of all "self-oriented" and "other-oriented" goal types assessed as a latent variable.  

Additionally, we will assess empathic and personal anger effects as state affect responses alongside experimental condition. In these analyses we will still use Hayes' PROCESS macro and SEM to assess the empathic/personal anger --> decisional goal --> interpersonal decision mediation effect.  

All analyses will control for baselines positive and negative affect. Additionally, the primary analyses will conduct hypothesis tests without any covariates. As a follow-up analysis, we will assess the hypothesized relationships with the trait variable covariates controlled for.  Additionally, zero-inflated poisson regression techniques will be employed alongside OLS hierarchical regression if interpersonal decision outcome distributions are found to violate assumptions of OLS regression.

*Note: These are not hypothesized interaction effects, but below I detail how the moderation research questions will be analyzed*

1.Personal/empathic anger experimental condition (dummy coded as 0,1)

2. State empathic responding measured as composite scores of the Batson Empathic Adjectives 

3. Decisional goals, measured by the Goals Following Interpersonal Transgressions Scale (GFIT, Rasmussen & Boone, 2018). Each goal will be calculated as a composite goal type based on the original scale paper. Additionally, a latent variable of "self-focused goals" and "other focused goals" will be computed, in which the Power, Reputation, Self-Protect, Avoiding Conflict, and Emotional Well-Being dimensions will be assessed as self-focused goals, and the Moral, Protect Others, Justice,  Education, and Forgiveness subscales will be assessed as other-focused goals. Scores for each goal type will be computed as averages for each goal's specific items. 

4. Interpersonal decisions, measured as whether participants choose to reallocate task assignments for themselves (self-compensation), a third party (third party compensation), the offender (punishment) or no one (escape). Measured as a score from 0-20 for intensity of reallocation, and also as a category (type of help).

5. Trait mindfulness, measured as a composite score on the Mindful Attention and Awareness Scale (Brown & Ryan, 2003). Scores are calculated as an average of the fifteen items in the scale.

6. Trait curiosity, measured with the Five Dimension Curiosity Scale (Kashdan et al., 2017). Social curiosity is expected to be the most strongly related curiosity construct, but all five dimensions of curiosity will be assessed as possible moderators. Curiosity scores are computed as the average of the items for each curiosity dimension subscale.

a) experimental condition on interpersonal decisions and motivational goals, and 
b) state empathic responding on interpersonal decisions and motivational goals

1. Task reallocation operationalized as third-party compensation (reallocating task to reduce workload for third partner), third-party punishment (reallocating task to increase workload for the leader who originally allocated the task), self-compensation (reallocating task to reduce workload for self), and escape from the situation (choosing not to make any decision).

2. Motivational goals to engage in interpersonal decisions was measured using the Decisional Goals Questionnaire
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b:
1. Trait variables: 
a.   Five-factor trait curiosity (Kashdan et al., 2018). Social curiosity is the main dimension of curiosity predicted to influence empathy and interpersonal behavior, but all other facets will be tested as well.
b.   Mindful attention and awareness (Brown & Ryan, 2003). 

2. Decision cost experimental condition: two conditions (high cost, low cost), between-subjects, orthogonal, measured as moderator

3. Trait variables assessed as screening variables and covariates - I will assess for univariate and multivariate outliers for these variables, and will test our hypotheses both with and without these variables. Our main predictions will be tested without these covariates, and as a secondary follow-up test we will assess hypothesis tests with these covariates added as controls. Covariate traits include:
a. Dispositional aggression measured by the Brief Aggression Questionnaire (Webster et al., 2015). 
b. Need to belong measured by the Need to Belong Scale (Leary, Kelly, Cottrell, & Schreindorfer, 2013). 
c. Sadistic impulses will be measured by the Short Sadistic Impulse Scale (SSIS, O’Meara et al., 2011). 
d. Dispositional empathic anger measured by the Trait Empathic Anger Scale (TEAS; Vitaglione & Barnett, 2003).
e. Trait empathy will be measured by the Questionnaire Measure for Cognitive and Affective Empathy (Reniers et al., 2011). 

4. State variables used for screening - I will control for baselines positive and negative affect in all analyses. Positive and negative affect will be measured using the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988), as well as post-task positive emotion measured by the Discrete Emotions Questionnaire (Harmon-Jones et al., 2016).
