registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
*STUDY 1*

Purpose:
Study 1 will build on prior research by directly comparing personal anger and empathic anger on motivation to self-compensate, escape a retaliation situation, help a third party, or punish an offender. Only a few studies have directly compared these two states within a single experiment (David et al., 2017; FeldmanHall et al., 2015; Gummerum et al., 2016; Omara et al., 2011), but none of these offered self-compensation and escape together as behavioral options in response to unfairness. Additionally, no studies of empathic anger have directly measured self-focused and other-focused goals as mediators of anger effects on behavioral decisions. Study 1 will also constrain participants to choose one behavioral response (either helping, punishment, self-compensation, or escape) so as to conceptually replicate findings that individuals are more likely to choose self-compensation than punishment when they are personally angered by an offender (FeldmanHall et al., 2015), but are more likely to compensate a victim or punish an offender when a third party is treated unfairly (Gummerum et al., 2016; van Prooijen, 2010).

Design and Participants:
Study 1 will have two conditions: Empathic Anger and Personal Anger. Based on a pilot study's finding that personal and empathic anger predict different levels of prosocial activity motivation at d = .46, we conducted a power analysis to determine the number of participants needed to detect this effect size  within a moderation analysis (which would involve measuring 2 factors and an interaction). A power analysis in G*Power indicated that 151 participants would be needed to detect an interaction effect size of d = .46 between two groups and a continuous factor with 80% power and α = .05. Based on this power analysis, study 1 will recruit a minimum of 200 adult participants recruited through MTurk, who will be compensated $1.00 each. 

Measures and Procedure:
Participants will complete the study through an electronic questionnaire system (Qualtrics) which will present study tasks and information. After indicating their informed consent, they will first read the instructions for the MTPP (see below for full description) and respond to a short quiz indicating they understand the instructions. Participants will enter their name, and both they and the other participants will be referred to by name (rather than “third player”, etc.). Participants will then complete the following measures/tasks:

Baseline Positive and Negative Affect. To control for individual differences in positive and negative affect entering the study, participants will first respond to the short form of the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988). Participants report how strongly they feel emotions with positive valence (e.g., “Alert”) and negative valence (e.g., “Afraid”) on a 1 (Not at all) to 5 (Extremely) scale.

Moderator Variables: Participants will complete two trait variable questionnaires, including:
 
a. Mindful Attention and Awareness Scale. Participants' trait mindfulness will be measured by the MAAS (Brown & Ryan, 2003). The scale is listed on a 1 (almost always) to 6 (almost never) scale with questions asking about tendencies to act mindlessly (e.g., "I could be experiencing some emotion and not be conscious of it until some time later").

b. Five-Factor Trait Curiosity (Kashdan et al., 2018). Lastly participants will complete a trait measure of curiosity, the five-factor curiosity scale. Participants respond to questions about their curiosity habits (e.g., "I like to learn about the habits of others") on a 1 (Does not describe me at all) to 7 (Describes me completely) scale.

Anger Condition and Modified Third-Party Punishment Task. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive the Personal Anger or Empathic Anger condition and will complete the MTPP task. In the prototypical Third-Party Punishment task (Fehr & Fishbacher, 2003), participants witness a "dictator" participant allocate unfair amounts of money to a "recipient" participant. This unfair allocation has been shown to elicit personal anger when the participant is the recipient, and empathic anger when the participant is a third-party witness to the allocation decision (Fehr & Fishbacher, 2003). In the MTPP, the same type of allocation paradigm is used but task assignments, rather than money, are allocated. This modified task will allow us to examine how reactions to unfairness generalize beyond monetary decisions.

In the MTPP, participants are given a cover story that the study is researching group behavior, specifically “how groups of people task delegation decisions in groups online vs. in-person.” The participant will ostensibly be paired with two other partners online through a university research server. In actuality, the participant is the only player, and the two partners are computerized.

Participants will read that the first part of the study will involve the group members choosing how to delegate a set of tasks. The tasks involve rating and describing three sets of pictures which have been shown to elicit minimal affective responses (e.g., a floppy disc or lamp). There are to be two rounds of photos to describe in the study. One of the participants will be randomly assigned to choose how many photos each group member must complete (the group leader). Participants then rate and describe one example photo, and then will respond to attention check questions to indicate they understand the point of the study.

The computer player "Alex" is chosen to be the delegator for the photo tasks. Participants are shown the following allocations based on their experimental condition fr Round 1 (object photos).

- Personal Anger: Total number of photos is 15. Participant is assigned 10 photos to describe; second group member is assigned 5 photos to describe; group leader assigns him/herself 0 photos.

- Empathic Anger: Total number of photos is 30. Participant is assigned 10 photos to describe; second group member is assigned 20 photos to describe; group leader assigns him/herself 0 photos.

Participants then have the opportunity to write a public message to the other participants. Because the players are all computerized, the participant will see predetermined answers, with their own comment added to make it look like all players have posted messages to each other. On the next page, all of the players' messages are posted.

Next, participants will actually complete the photo description assignment, and will rate and describe 10 photos (descriptions must be 100 characters at least). After completing this assignment, participants will either see a waiting screen making them wait for a few seconds while the other players complete the task (if in the empathic anger condition), or they will immediately move to the next part of the group study.

Empathy and State Affect. After Round 1 of the MTPP task and after seeing the allocation choice for Round 2, participants will report their empathic and personal anger, empathic concern, personal distress, and positive affect immediately before making the Round 2 reallocation decision. All emotions will be rated from 1 (Not at all) to 7 (Extremely).

Empathic Anger. The State Empathic Anger Scale (SEAS; Vitaglione & Barnett, 2003) measures anger felt on behalf of another person. including eight emotional adjectives (mad, angry, furious, resentful, irritated, enraged, aggravated, outraged).

Empathic Concern and Distress. Empathic concern and distress will be measured through Batson’s Emotional Adjective Scale (BEAS; Batson, Fultz, & Schoenrade, 1987), consisting of 14 emotional adjectives measuring other-oriented concern (sympathetic, warm, softhearted, moved, compassionate, tender) and self-focused personal distress (troubled, upset, worried, disturbed, grieved, alarmed, perturbed, distressed).

Positive Affect. Positive affect will be measured with the Happiness and Relaxation subscales of the Discrete Emotions Questionnaire (Harmon-Jones et al., 2016).

On the next page, participants will be told the group leader will choose the next task allocation, which will be completed at the end of the study. They are told there are now 40 photos to be completed, and both the participant and the other group member have been assigned 20 of the 40 photos. The group leader (Alex) assigns themselves 0.

After seeing the Round 2 allocation, participants report their state empathy and affect once more. Next, participants are also then told that they have been selected as the moderator for Round 2 of the study. Participants then choose whether they want to reallocate photos for themselves, the group leader, or the partner participant. Once they make this decision, they then choose how many photos to reallocate (0 - 20). Later, participants will learn that they do not in fact need to complete this final rating/description task.

Reallocation Decision. In Round 2, participants will have the option to reallocate photos for themselves (self-compensation), the third player (third party helping), or the group leader (punishment). They also have the option of not changing any photos (Escape).

Decisional Goals. To assess participants’ goals when choosing their helping/punishment/escape decision, participants will complete the Goals Following Interpersonal Transgressions scale (GFIT; Rasmussen & Boon, 2017). The full scale measures 12 dimensions of behavioral motivation following an interpersonal transgression. For the current study, only the Power, Moral, Reputation, Protect Others, Self-Protect, Emotional Well-Being, Justice, and Education subscales will be included. Participants rate on a 1 (not at all strongly) to 7 (very strongly) scale the extent to which they held each goal in making their decision. In analyses, the Power, Reputation, Self-Protect, Avoiding Conflict, and Emotional Well-Being dimensions will be assessed as self-focused goals, and the Moral, Protect Others, Justice, Education, and Forgiveness subscales will be assessed as other-focused goals.

Post-Decision Affect. Participants will be asked to report their state affect once more using the Discrete Emotions Questionnaire in order to assess whether helping or punishment decisions positively influenced participants’ mood.

Trait Measures. Finally, participants will complete a questionnaire including a number of trait measures. These measures will be assessed after the primary measures of interest so as to not prime participants with concepts of anger or empathy.

Trait Empathic Anger. Trait empathic anger is the extent to which participants tend to feel empathic anger in their daily lives, and will be measured using the Trait Empathic Anger Scale (TEAS; Vitaglione & Barnett, 2003), a seven-item Likert-scale ranging from 1 (Does Not Describe Me Very Well) to 5 (Describes Me Very Well); e.g. “I feel angry for other people when they have been victimized by others.”

Trait Anger and Aggression. The dispositional tendency to get angry across different situations will be measured with the Brief Aggression Questionnaire (Webster et al., 2015). This measure asks participants to report how they would describe themselves on a 1 (Does not describe me at all) to 5 (Describes me very well) scale, (e.g., “Given enough provocation, I may hit another person”).

Need to Belong. The dispositional need to belong and feel social support will be measured by the Need to Belong Scale (Leary, Kelly, Cottrell, & Schreindorfer, 2013). This asks participants to report on a 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree) scale to what extent they generally are distressed by social exclusion or desire social connection (e.g., “If other people don't seem to accept me, I don't let it bother me”).

Sadistic Impulses. Participants' tendencies to want to hurt others in everyday life will be measured by the Short Sadistic Impulse Scale (SSIS, O’Meara et al., 2011). The scale is listed on a 1 (Strongly disagree) to 7 (Strongly agree) scale (e.g., “Hurting people would be exciting”).

Final Description: Participants are finally informed that they will not be asked to complete the Round 2 rating assignment. They will then be asked to complete their demographics and a final short cooldown task before finishing the study.

Demographics. Participants’ gender, race, and age will be self-reported.

Cooldown task: Participants will be asked to complete the same emotional cooldown task described in Study 3 in order to mitigate the psychological effects of having been induced to feel anger.

End-of-study Mood. To determine whether participants are leaving the study in a positive or neutral emotional state, they will lastly be asked to complete a short mood questionnaire. This measure will be used only to monitor participants' responses, and thus will only include only 1 item in order to minimize participant frustration given the high quantity of affective self-report questionnaires in the study. The item will ask "Overall, how positive or negative is your mood right now?" and will utilize a sliding scale ranging from -100 ('Extremely negative; the worst I've felt in a long time') to 100 ('Extremely positive; the best I've felt in a long time') with a midpoint of 0 ('Completely neutral; neither positive or negative').

Afterward, participants will be fully debriefed with a written letter explaining the purpose of the study and the deception elements.



*STUDY 2*
Study 2 will again compare the effects of personal and empathic anger on motivation to help, punish, or self-compensate while additionally assessing the effect of high or low personal cost through adding a “payment” aspect to participant decisions. High-cost payments will consist of SONA credits whereas low-cost payments will consist of raffle ticket entries for a separate prize above and beyond SONA credit compensation. SONA credits are expected to be perceived as more valuable as participants (undergraduate students enrolled in Introduction to Psychology) must obtain a certain number of credits in order to pass their Introduction to Psychology class. If empathic anger predicts similar levels of helping, punishment, and other-focused goals in the high and low-cost conditions, this will be more direct evidence of altruism than what has been posited in past literature.

Study 2 includes the same hypotheses as Study 1 as well as a moderation hypothesis:

H6. Decision cost will interact with experimental condition to predict participants' decision to self-compensate, helping, and punishment decisions, such that:
a.   Across all conditions, participants will be more likely to self-compensate in the high cost condition compared to the low cost condition.
b.   The difference between decision outcomes in the high and low cost conditions will be stronger in the personal anger condition than the empathic anger condition. 

Method
Design: Study 2 will have a 2 (Empathic vs. Personal Anger) x 2 (High vs. Low Cost) factorial design. Using the same d = .46 effect size as Study 1, a power analysis indicated that 211participants would be adequate to detect main and interaction effect sizes of similar magnitude with 80% power and α = .05 using ANCOVA (controlling for time of semester and baseline affect).

Participants: Participants in Study 2 will be either undergraduate students at VCU participating for course credit (1 SONA credit) and entered to win a raffle for several gift cards.

Procedure. Participants will complete the study in groups of three or more in a computer lab setting at Virginia Commonwealth University for 1 SONA credit (or will complete the study online through the MTurk website at www.mturk.com). After informed consent they will complete the following measures and tasks.

Baseline Positive and Negative Affect. Participants will first complete the PANAS as a measure of baseline positive and negative affect.

Moderator Variables: Participants will complete the Mindful Attention and Awareness Scale and the Five-Factor Trait Curiosity Scale.

Modified Third-Party Punishment Game. Participants will first read the instructions for the MTPP as described in Study 1, and will respond to a short quiz indicating they understand the instructions. Participants will then enter their name, and both they and the other participants will be referred to by name (rather than “third player” or group leader). They will then be randomly assigned to the Personal Anger or Empathic Anger condition of the study, and will complete the MTPP as described in Study 1.

Once participants have been brought to the Round 2 reallocation task, they will be randomly assigned to the High Cost or Low Cost condition. Unlike Study 1 where participants could choose how to reallocate the photos freely, now participants must "pay" to reallocate photo tasks.

High Cost Condition. In the high-cost condition, participants will have to "pay" for photo reallocation with SONA credit or from their MTurk compensation. They will be instructed that they can pay up to .05 SONA credits or $0.05 from their final compensation amount in order to reallocate photos in each round, with .05 credits/dollars per photo. The amount of credit they pay to reallocate will ostensibly be taken from their final credit amount. (In actuality, participants will receive their full credit amount at the end of the study).

Low Cost Condition. In the low-cost condition, participants will have to pay for photo reallocation with entries to the gift card raffle. They will be told that each participant receives 20 raffle ticket entries, and they can pay between 0 and 20 entries to reallocate photos, with one raffle entry being equal to one photo reallocations. The number of raffle entries they pay will ostensibly be taken from their final compensation amount. (In actuality, participants will receive the full number of entries at the end of the study).

Decisional Goals. To assess participants’ goals when choosing their helping/punishment/escape decision, participants will complete the Goals Following Interpersonal Transgressions scale (GFIT; Rasmussen & Boon, 2017). The full scale measures 12 dimensions of behavioral motivation following an interpersonal transgression. For the current study, only the Power, Moral, Reputation, Protect Others, Self-Protect, Emotional Well-Being, Justice, and Education subscales will be included. Participants rate on a 1 (not at all strongly) to 7 (very strongly) scale the extent to which they held each goal in making their decision. In analyses, the Power, Reputation, Self-Protect, Avoiding Conflict, and Emotional Well-Being dimensions will be assessed as self-focused goals, and the Moral, Protect Others, Justice, Education, and Forgiveness subscales will be assessed as other-focused goals.

Post-Decision Affect. Participants will be asked to report their state affect once more using the Discrete Emotions Questionnaire in order to assess whether helping or punishment decisions positively influenced participants’ mood.

Manipulation Check. Participants will respond to three manipulation check questions to determine that the two anger conditions are perceived to be equally unfair, and that the high-cost payment tokens (SONA credits) are perceived to be more important than the low-cost payment tokens (raffle ticket entries).
1) How fair did you think the photo rating task allocation was? (1 = completely unfair, 7 = completely fair)
2) How important was it to you that you got the maximum number of SONA credits [raffle entries] as you could? (1 = not at all important, 7 = extremely important).
3) Have you ever completed a task similar to the photo rating task in other studies or as part of a class?

Trait Measures. Finally, participants will complete a questionnaire including a number of trait measures. These measures will be assessed after the primary measures of interest so as to not prime participants with concepts of anger or empathy.

Trait Empathic Anger. Trait empathic anger is the extent to which participants tend to feel empathic anger in their daily lives, and will be measured using the Trait Empathic Anger Scale (TEAS; Vitaglione & Barnett, 2003), a seven-item Likert-scale ranging from 1 (Does Not Describe Me Very Well) to 5 (Describes Me Very Well); e.g. “I feel angry for other people when they have been victimized by others.”

Trait Anger and Aggression. The dispositional tendency to get angry across different situations will be measured with the Brief Aggression Questionnaire (Webster et al., 2015). This measure asks participants to report how they would describe themselves on a 1 (Does not describe me at all) to 5 (Describes me very well) scale, (e.g., “Given enough provocation, I may hit another person”).

Need to Belong. The dispositional need to belong and feel social support will be measured by the Need to Belong Scale (Leary, Kelly, Cottrell, & Schreindorfer, 2013). This asks participants to report on a 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree) scale to what extent they generally are distressed by social exclusion or desire social connection (e.g., “If other people don't seem to accept me, I don't let it bother me”).

Sadistic Impulses. Participants' tendencies to want to hurt others in everyday life will be measured by the Short Sadistic Impulse Scale (SSIS, O’Meara et al., 2011). The scale is listed on a 1 (Strongly disagree) to 7 (Strongly agree) scale (e.g., “Hurting people would be exciting”).

Final Description: Participants are finally informed that they will not be asked to complete the Round 2 rating assignment. They will then be asked to complete their demographics and a final short cooldown task before finishing the study.

Demographics. Participants’ gender, race, and age will be self-reported.

Cooldown task: Participants will be asked to complete the same emotional cooldown task described in Study 3 in order to mitigate the psychological effects of having been induced to feel anger.

End-of-study Mood. To determine whether participants are leaving the study in a positive or neutral emotional state, they will lastly be asked to complete a short mood questionnaire. This measure will be used only to monitor participants' responses, and thus will only include only 1 item in order to minimize participant frustration given the high quantity of affective self-report questionnaires in the study. The item will ask "Overall, how positive or negative is your mood right now?" and will utilize a sliding scale ranging from -100 ('Extremely negative; the worst I've felt in a long time') to 100 ('Extremely positive; the best I've felt in a long time') with a midpoint of 0 ('Completely neutral; neither positive or negative').

Debriefing: Participants will be debriefed about the true purpose of the study, and will be told that they will receive the full compensation amount regardless of how many photos they reallocated in the study.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
Variables: 

1. Personal/empathic anger experimental condition (dummy coded with personal anger = 0)

2. State empathic responding measured as composite scores of the Batson Empathic Adjectives Scale and State Empathic Anger Scale

3. Interpersonal decisions, measured as whether participants choose to reallocate task assignments for themselves (self-compensation), a third party (third party compensation), the offender (punishment) or no one (escape). Measured as a score from 0-20 for intensity of reallocation, and also as a category (type of help).

1) Hierarchical logistic regression will test whether anger condition is a significant predictor of self-compensation, helping, punishment, and escape interpersonal decisions while controlling for baseline positive and negative affect. In study 2, time in the semester will also be controlled for as the sample will be students participating in a lab setting.

2) Hierarchical OLS regression will test anger condition is a significant predictor of the continuous outcome measure of self-compensation, helping, punishment, and escape interpersonal decisions while controlling for baseline positive and negative affect (and time in the semester in study 2).

For both analyses, I will conduct the primary hypothesis tests without any covariates. Additionally as a follow-up analysis, I will assess the hypothesized relationships with the trait variable covariates controlled for.

Anger condition: IV
State empathic responding: IV
Third-party compensation: DV
Third-party punishment: DV
Self-compensation: DV

Baseline affect used as a covariate to control for participants' potentially having a very strong positive or negative mood prior to exposure to the unfair scenario. In study 2, time in semester will be controlled for because in the high decision cost condition participants are asked to spend part of their SOAN credit, which is used toward their course credit for their Intro to Psychology class. Participants toward the end of the semester, when they may be more focused on getting course credit quickly, may be more influenced by decision cost than participants earlier in the semester.
Bayesian techniques are not planned for this analysis. However we may employ Bayesian techniques as an exploratory follow-up analysis.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi:
Variables: 

1. Personal/empathic anger experimental condition (dummy coded with personal anger = 0)

2. State empathic responding measured as composite scores of the Batson Empathic Adjectives Scale and State Empathic Anger Scale

3. Decisional goals, measured by the Goals Following Interpersonal Transgressions Scale (GFIT, Rasmussen & Boone, 2018). Each goal will be calculated as a composite goal type based on the original scale paper. Additionally, a latent variable of "self-focused goals" and "other focused goals" will be computed, in which the Power, Reputation, Self-Protect, Avoiding Conflict, and Emotional Well-Being dimensions will be assessed as self-focused goals, and the Moral, Protect Others, Justice,  Education, and Forgiveness subscales will be assessed as other-focused goals. 

4. Interpersonal decisions, measured as whether participants choose to reallocate task assignments for themselves (self-compensation), a third party (third party compensation), the offender (punishment) or no one (escape). Measured as a score from 0-20 for intensity of reallocation, and also as a category (type of help).

Hayes' PROCESS macro will be used to estimate the bootstrapped indirect effect of experimental condition on interpersonal decisions through the mediator of decisional goals (each goal type separately). Additionally a structural equation model will be computed to assess the mediational effect of all "self-oriented" and "other-oriented" goal types assessed as a latent variable.  

Additionally, we will assess empathic and personal anger effects as state affect responses alongside experimental condition. In these analyses we will still use Hayes' PROCESS macro and SEM to assess the empathic/personal anger --> decisional goal --> interpersonal decision mediation effect.  

All analyses will control for baselines positive and negative affect. Additionally, the primary analyses will conduct hypothesis tests without any covariates. As a follow-up analysis, we will assess the hypothesized relationships with the trait variable covariates controlled for.  Additionally, zero-inflated poisson regression techniques will be employed alongside OLS hierarchical regression if interpersonal decision outcome distributions are found to violate assumptions of OLS regression.

Experimental condition: IV
State empathic responding: IV
Decisional goals: mediator
Interpersonal decisions: DV

Baseline affect used as a covariate to control for participants' potentially having a very strong positive or negative mood prior to exposure to the unfair scenario. In study 2, time in semester will be controlled for because in the high decision cost condition participants are asked to spend part of their SOAN credit, which is used toward their course credit for their Intro to Psychology class. Participants toward the end of the semester, when they may be more focused on getting course credit quickly, may be more influenced by decision cost than participants earlier in the semester.
Bayesian techniques are not planned for this analysis. However we may employ Bayesian techniques as an exploratory follow-up analysis.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Participants will volunteer to be a part of the study. Participants younger than 18 or who have completed a study with similar measures are excluded from participating. Participants who express suspicion about the deceptive elements of the study will be screened from final analyses.

Study 1: Participants will be adults aged 18 or older from the US participating on Amazon MTurk.

Study 2: Participants will be college students aged 18 or older participating for course credit.

Study 1 will have two conditions (Empathic Anger and Personal Anger). Drawing from a pilot test finding that personal and empathic anger predict different levels of prosocial activity motivation at d = .46, a power analysis indicated that 150 participants would be adequate to detect a similar main effect and interactions of a similar effect size (i.e., the difference between two independent samples) with 80% power and α = .05. Study 1 will recruit a minimum of 150 adult participants recruited through MTurk. 

Study 2 will have a 2 (Empathic vs. Personal Anger) x 2 (High vs. Low Cost) factorial design. Using the same d = .23 effect size as Study 1, a power analysis indicated that 211 participants would be adequate to detect main or interaction effect sizes of similar magnitude with 80% power and α = .05 using ANCOVA (controlling for time of semester and baseline affect). Because the effect size of interest may be smaller, we will continue to collect participants past this minimum in order to increase power.

S1: Data collection will be terminated once 300 MTurk participants have participated.  If participants must be removed from analyses due to suspicion and this reduced the sample below that required by the power analysis, data collection will resume until the minimum required by the power analysis is achieved with non-suspicious participants.

S2: Data collection will be terminated on March 1, 2020, or once the minimum number of participants indicated by the power analysis has been collected.  If participants must be removed from analyses due to suspicion and this reduced the sample below that required by the power analysis, data collection will resume until this minimum is achieved with non-suspicious participants.

For both analyses, I will conduct the primary hypothesis tests without any covariates. Additionally as a follow-up analysis, I will assess the hypothesized relationships with the trait variable covariates controlled for.

registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-further.further.qu:
*Note: These are not hypothesized interaction effects, but below I detail how the moderation research questions will be analyzed*

1.Personal/empathic anger experimental condition (dummy coded as 0,1)

2. State empathic responding measured as composite scores of the Batson Empathic Adjectives 

3. Decisional goals, measured by the Goals Following Interpersonal Transgressions Scale (GFIT, Rasmussen & Boone, 2018). Each goal will be calculated as a composite goal type based on the original scale paper. Additionally, a latent variable of "self-focused goals" and "other focused goals" will be computed, in which the Power, Reputation, Self-Protect, Avoiding Conflict, and Emotional Well-Being dimensions will be assessed as self-focused goals, and the Moral, Protect Others, Justice,  Education, and Forgiveness subscales will be assessed as other-focused goals. Scores for each goal type will be computed as averages for each goal's specific items. 

4. Interpersonal decisions, measured as whether participants choose to reallocate task assignments for themselves (self-compensation), a third party (third party compensation), the offender (punishment) or no one (escape). Measured as a score from 0-20 for intensity of reallocation, and also as a category (type of help).

5. Trait mindfulness, measured as a composite score on the Mindful Attention and Awareness Scale (Brown & Ryan, 2003). Scores are calculated as an average of the fifteen items in the scale.

6. Trait curiosity, measured with the Five Dimension Curiosity Scale (Kashdan et al., 2017). Social curiosity is expected to be the most strongly related curiosity construct, but all five dimensions of curiosity will be assessed as possible moderators. Curiosity scores are computed as the average of the items for each curiosity dimension subscale.

Hierarchical OLS regression and logistic regression, as well as Hayes' PROCESS macro will be used to analyze whether decision cost, trait mindfulness, and trait curiosity moderate the effects of: 
a) experimental condition on interpersonal decisions and motivational goals, and 
b) state empathic responding on interpersonal decisions and motivational goals

State empathic responding: IV

Trait mindfulness: moderator
Trait curiosity: moderator

registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
Participants will be excluded from analyses for the following reasons:
- If participants miss two or more attention check questions
- If participants fail an additional suspicion probe and indicate they did not believe the experimental manipulation
- If there is evidence to suggest participants are bots (e.g., suspicious answers, repeated geographical coordinates outside the US as described by Bai (2018) (see https://www.maxhuibai.com/blog/evidence-that-responses-from-repeating-gps-are-random)
- Evidence suggests participants were not paying attention (a final question asking participants about their work quality, overly consistent reponses)

attributes.title: Revisiting Empathy Deficits in Psychopathy
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

question2a.value: We will manipulate empathy scenario as a within-participants factor, such that participants will respond to both empathic-distress and empathic-anger scenarios.

question2b.value: We will measure psychopathy dimensions from two-, three-, and four-factor models (conceptualized as IVs). We will measure relative other-agency and relative situational control appraisals, perceived target emotional responses, vicarious emotional responses, vicarious emotional sensitivity, and emotional congruence (conceptualized as DVs).

question3b.value: Gender will function as a covariate in some exploratory analyses.

question10b.value:
Participants will consent to an online study purported to investigate how people judge social situations. The study will comprise two parts to be completed in succession. In Part 1, participants will complete two-factor, Triarchic (three-factor), and four-factor measures of psychopathy. 
In Part 2, we will employ a vignette-based approach to assess empathic responding (for this approach in a similar context of assessing perceived target emotional responses, see Tiedens, Ellsworth, & Mesquita, 2000). For generality, we composed four vignettes (see below), each depicting an empathy-evoking story detailing an unfortunate situation that befalls a target with a gender-neutral designation. Scenario endings were modified, based on an appraisal-based framework (Smith & Ellsworth, 1985), to evoke “empathic distress” vs. “empathic anger.” For empathic-distress scenarios, we manipulated the story’s resolution so that the unfortunate situation would be perceived to be beyond anyone’s control (e.g., “Sam soon finds out that the reason s/he is being fired is because of poor economic conditions that have disproportionately affected people with Sam’s specialized skills.”). This situation should stimulate an affect responsivity system that, according to Blair (2003), is sensitive to distress (e.g., fear and sadness) expressions. For empathic-anger scenarios, we manipulated the story’s resolution the unfortunate situation was not beyond anyone’s control and someone other than the target was responsible for causing it (e.g., “Sam soon finds out that the reason s/he is being fired is not because of bad economic conditions but, instead, because Sam’s boss was envious of Sam and wanted to sabotage Sam’s career.”). This situation should stimulate an affect responsivity system that, according to Blair (2003), is sensitive to stimuli indicative of violating social norms or expectations.
	Participants will read each vignette with each story ending. After each ending, participants will rate appraisals of relative other-agency and relative situational control as manipulation checks for the empathy scenario manipulation. Participants will also rate a) the extent to which they perceive the target would feel angry, sad, and afraid (i.e., perceived target emotional responses) and b) the extent to which they feel angry, sad, and afraid for the target (i.e., vicarious emotional responses). We will compute variables that index the relative difference between the latter and former (i.e., vicarious emotional sensitivity) and the absolute difference between the latter and former (i.e., emotional congruence). Finally, participants will be debriefed after completing demographics (age, race, gender).
Measures
Levenson Self-Report Psychopathy (LSRP; Levenson et al., 1995). The LSRP is a 26-item two-factor measure of psychopathy which summates items into primary psychopathy (e.g., “I enjoy manipulating other people's feelings.”) and secondary psychopathy (e.g., “I find myself in the same kinds of trouble, time after time.”). Factor-analytic evidence has supported this two-factor structure (e.g., Salekin, Chen, Sellbom, Lester, & MacDougall, 2014). Participants will rate (dis)agreement with each statement (1 = disagree strongly, 4 = agree strongly).
Triarchic Personality Measure (TriPM; Patrick et al., 2009). The TriPM is a 58-item three-factor measure of psychopathy which summates items into Triarchic dimensions of boldness (e.g., “I can get over things that would traumatize others.”), disinhibition (e.g., “I often act on immediate needs.”), and meanness (e.g., “I don't care much if what I do hurts others.”). Participants will rate the extent to which each statement describes them (1 = true, 4 = false). 
Self-Report Psychology Scale IV – Short Form (SRP-SF; Paulhus et al., 2016). The SRP-SF is a 29-item four-factor measure of psychopathy which summates items into psychopathic features of interpersonal manipulation (e.g., “A lot of people are ‘suckers’ and can easily be fooled.”), callous affect (e.g., “I never feel guilty over hurting others.”), erratic lifestyle (e.g., “I rarely follow the rules.”), and antisocial behavior (e.g., “I have assaulted a law enforcement official or social worker.”). The SRP-SF is an abbreviated version of the full 64-item SRP and is conceptually analogous to the four factors postulated by Hare’s Psychopathy Checklist – Revised (PCL-R; Hare, 2003). Participants will rate (dis)agreement with each statement (1 = disagree strongly, 5 = agree strongly).
Relative other-agency appraisals. For one of our manipulation checks, we adapted items from Smith and Ellsworth (1985) to assess, by condition, the extent to which (1 = not at all, 7 = extremely) participants believed that (1) someone other than the target was responsible for the target having [endured the unfortunate outcome] in this situation (other-agency) and (2) the target was responsible for having [endured the unfortunate outcome] in this situation (self-agency). Items will be averaged across vignettes to create aggregate indices. We will compute a discrepancy score by subtracting self-agency from other-agency, thereby creating an index of relative other-agency appraisals. Positive scores denote appraisals of higher other-agency compared to self-agency. 
Relative situational control appraisals. For our other manipulation check, we adapted items from Smith and Ellsworth (1985) to assess, by condition, the extent to which (1 = not at all, 7 = extremely) participants believed that (1) circumstances beyond anyone’s control were controlling whether the target [endured the unfortunate outcome] in this situation (situational control) and (2) the target had the ability to influence whether s/he [endured the unfortunate outcome] in this situation (self-control). Items will be averaged across vignettes. We will compute a discrepancy score by subtracting self-control from situational control, thereby creating an index of relative situational control appraisals. Positive scores denote appraisals of higher situational control compared to self-control.   
	Perceived target emotional responses. Participants will rate the extent to which (1 = not at all, 7 = extremely) the target would feel the following “emotion concepts”: anger (treated unfairly, angry, boiling inwardly), sadness (a sense of loss, sad, helpless), and fear (uncertain, afraid, a desire to avoid). Inspired by the framework proposed in Frijda (1986), each emotion concept encompasses an item representing the cognitive-structural component, the feeling component, and the action tendency, respectively. According to Frijda, Kuipers, and ter Schure (1989), an emotional state may be incomplete without considering all three components. Items will be averaged across vignettes.
	Vicarious emotional responses. Participants will rate the extent to which (1 = not at all, 7 = extremely) they feel the following “emotion concepts” for the target: anger (treated unfairly, angry, boiling inwardly), sadness (a sense of loss, sad, helpless), and fear (uncertain, afraid, a desire to avoid). Items will be averaged across vignettes.
	Vicarious emotional sensitivity. We will compute “relative discrepancy scores” by subtracting perceived target emotional responses from respective vicarious emotional responses, thereby creating indices of vicarious emotional sensitivity for each emotion. Positive scores represent vicarious emotional sensitivity (i.e., the vicarious response overwhelms the target appraisal), whereas negative scores represent vicarious emotional insensitivity (i.e., the target appraisal overwhelms the vicarious response).
	Emotional congruence. We will compute “absolute discrepancy scores” by taking the absolute value of each index of vicarious emotional sensitivity and multiplying the result by -1 (for a similar approach to computing empathy, Kraus, Côté, & Keltner, 2010). Thus, higher scores denote greater emotional congruence and, hence, approaches greater “empathy.”


Empathy Vignettes
Vignette 1
"Sam has worked for the same company for the past 10 years. Sam is known as a hard-working and talented employee at the company. Sam loves his/her job and has demonstrated a selfless commitment to helping the company grow and thrive. Unfortunately, Sam just learned that s/he will be laid off at the end of the month. Sam’s unemployment will likely have a devastating impact on Sam and Sam’s family, such that they will struggle to pay bills and have enough food to eat."

Empathic-Distress Scenario Ending: “Sam soon finds out that the reason s/he is being fired is because of poor economic conditions that have disproportionately affected people with Sam’s specialized skills.” 

Empathic-Anger Scenario Ending: “Sam soon finds out that the reason s/he is being fired is because Sam’s boss was envious of Sam and wanted to sabotage Sam’s career”


Vignette 2
 “Taylor is a talented and hard-working track athlete. Taylor has been training all of his/her life to be an Olympic track athlete. Due to hard work and dedication, Taylor has been named as the next rising star to run in the Olympics. Unfortunately, Taylor tripped and fell during the Olympic qualifiers, finishing in last place. Taylor did not qualify for the Olympics and must wait four more years to attempt another Olympic qualifier. Taylor will lose all of his/her endorsements, which is most of Taylor’s annual income.”

Empathic-Distress Scenario Ending: “Taylor soon finds out that the reason s/he tripped and fell was because it rained the night before, making the track extremely slick in Taylor’s inside lane which was collecting water.”

Empathic-Anger Scenario Ending: “Taylor soon finds out that the reason s/he tripped and fell was because a rival had poured a slippery liquid in Taylor’s lane before the race in order to take Taylor’s spot on the qualifying team.”



Vignette 3
“Morgan owns a thriving steakhouse. Morgan is completely dedicated to his/her restaurant, putting in long hours and a considerable amount of money into keeping the restaurant running. Morgan’s reputation has attracted attention from elite restaurant reviewers who have decided to review Morgan’s restaurant. This is an incredible opportunity for Morgan. Unfortunately, Morgan’s staff served steak that made all of the customers – including the reviewers – violently ill. The incident became public, and the Department of Public Health was forced to shut down Morgan’s restaurant due to health violations. Morgan lost his/her cherished restaurant.”

Empathic-Distress Scenario Ending: “Morgan soon finds out that the reason customers got sick was because of a local, unpreventable salmonella outbreak in one of their recent beef shipments.”

Empathic-Anger Scenario Ending: “Morgan soon finds out that the reason customers got sick was because a rival restaurateur tainted Morgan’s beef supply.”


Vignette 4
 “Jamie is a hard-working professional. Jamie’s dream has been to move his family into a beautiful, Victorian-style house in the neighborhood. Over the past 10 years, Jamie has been working overtime and multiple, part-time jobs. Finally, Jamie was able to save enough money to finally move his/her family into the new house. Unfortunately, the house caught fire one night and burned to the ground, just weeks after Jamie and his/her family moved in. Although nobody was injured, all of the family’s possessions were destroyed in the fire, including treasured and irreplaceable family heirlooms. Jamie’s insurance policy application had not yet been processed, so insurance will not cover Jamie for the losses.”

Empathic-Distress Scenario Ending: “Jamie soon finds out that the reason Jamie’s house burned down was because of a freak, unavoidable gas leak that ignited the fire.”

Empathic-Anger Scenario Ending: “Jamie soon finds out that the reason Jamie’s house burned down was because of a neighborhood delinquent who set fire to the home as a cruel prank.”

question4b.value: In an effort to increase the generalizability of our sample, we will recruit additional male participants so that the maximum female-to-male ratio is 3:2 (vs. 4:1 or greater, for example).

question5b.value: We will aim to recruit at least 300 undergraduates from the University of Alabama’s participant pool. Data will be collected via Qualtrics.

question6b.value: Sample size determinations were based on results in Schönbrodt and Perugini (2013), which indicated that parameter estimates for correlations typically stabilize around N = 250. Because some correlations in the proposed study will comprise difference scores and might require larger sample sizes to ensure reliable estimation, we will aim to recruit at least 300 undergraduates from the University of Alabama’s participant pool. This larger sample will also buffer against potential exclusions due to attrition and/or spurious cases.

question7b.value: Data will be collected until at least 120 males can be collected (but may exceed this number). At no point will data be analyzed before pre-registration or data collection has terminated.

question8b.value: Participants will be excluded if (a) they did not complete all measures and/or (b) they fail more than one of three attention checks, which suggests apathetic responding.

question1a.value:
The following are designated as confirmatory hypotheses (across conditions). Effect sizes will be interpreted based on benchmarks recommended in Funder and Ozer (2019), which suggested that extremely small/weak, small/weak, medium/moderate, large/strong, and very large/strong effects typically correspond with rs of .05, .10, .20, .30, and .40 or greater, respectively. For Hypothesis #1, psychopathy dimensions indicative of fearless dominance or callousness (i.e., primary psychopathy, boldness, meanness, affective features, and interpersonal features) will be the only dimensions to be inversely related (weakly-to-moderately) to perceived target emotion vis-à-vis sadness and fear but positively related (extremely weakly and approaching zero) to perceived target emotion vis-à-vis anger. For Hypothesis #2, these dimensions will be inversely related (weakly-to-moderately) to vicarious emotion vis-à-vis sadness and fear but positively related (extremely weakly and/or approaching zero) to vicarious emotion vis-à-vis anger. Hypotheses for potential, but extremely weak, relations between certain psychopathy dimensions and anger outcomes were motivated by theorizing and research indicating that psychopathy dimensions are associated with experiencing other-directed negative states (e.g., contempt, spite) which function to promote antagonism (Garofalo, Neumann, Zeigler-Hill, & Meloy, 2018). Because anger is part of this same classification, positive relations between psychopathy dimensions and anger outcomes would be sensible, even if their strength also depends on situational context. For Hypothesis #3, all psychopathy dimensions will be inversely related (extremely weakly and/or approaching zero) to vicarious sensitivity across emotion concepts. Likewise, for Hypothesis #4, all psychopathy dimensions will be extremely weakly related and approaching zero relations to emotional congruence, meaning that no strong evidence is anticipated for empathy to vary across psychopathy scores. 

We will run three sets of exploratory analyses. First, we will explore confirmatory analyses (i.e., Hypotheses 1-4) controlling for gender. Although psychopathy is subject to gender differences (i.e., men score higher, on average, on psychopathy dimensions than women; Miller, Watts, & Jones, 2011), we are devoid of a strong theoretical rationale to assume that our current conceptualization of empathy is similarly subject to gender differences. Thus, these analyses are most sensibly considered exploratory. Second, we will experimentally test a DMH explanation for Hypotheses 1 and 2. These exploratory hypotheses predict that the hypothesized relations vis-à-vis perceived target emotion and vicarious emotion will be moderated by whether the scenarios conceptually evoke empathic distress vs. empathic anger. In particular, relations between hypothesized psychopathy dimensions and empathy components of sadness and fear might be (weakly) attenuated for empathic-distress scenarios relative to empathic anger scenarios. This moderation would support the DMH because it suggests psychopathic people have a lower propensity for appraising unfortunate situations as being beyond someone’s control which is theorized to engender sadness and fear. In the context of these analyses, we will also explore interactions between psychopathy dimensions and empathy scenarios on empathy components of anger. Third, we will explore whether relations testing Hypotheses 1 and 2 can be independently explained by appraisals of situational contexts (e.g., the degree to which the unfortunate outcome was situationally-determined vs. self-determined). Indeed, under an appraisal-based theory, people higher in psychopathy dimensions indicative of fearless dominance or callousness might perceive lesser sadness or fear in targets and feel lesser sadness or fear for targets because they perceive the target (relative to the situation) as having greater control over the target’s outcome.

question2a.value: For exploratory interactive effects: For sadness or fear, we might expect that the effect of a hypothesized psychopathy dimension on each empathy component will be negative, but this negative effect will be attenuated in distress-based scenarios relative to anger scenarios. For anger, we might expect that the effect of a hypothesized dimension on each empathy component will be extremely weakly positive, but this effect will be strengthened in distress-based scenarios relative to anger scenarios.

question3a.value: We plan to submit scores on relative other-agency appraisals and relative situational control appraisals for each empathy scenario condition to separate dependent sample t-tests. We expect that participants will report higher relative other-agency appraisals and lower situational control appraisals in response to empathic anger scenarios compared to empathic distress scenarios. We anticipate medium-to-large effects.

Perceived target anger, sadness, and fear (averaged across three respective components and further averaged across vignettes).

question3c.value: Psychopathy dimensions (conceptualized as IV); perceived target emotional responses (conceptualized as DV)

question5c.value: In accordance with guidelines proposed in Amrhein, Trafimow, and Greenland (2019), we plan to address the limitation of statistical significance dichotomization by focusing discussion of our data on parameter estimates (i.e., effect sizes based on recommendations in Funder and Ozer, 2019). Supplementary statistical information pertaining to compatibility with the null hypothesis (dimensional p-values) and compatibility of effect sizes within the current sample (95% confidence intervals) will be presented for richer insight into the data. Thus, no inferences about “statistical significance” will be drawn.

Empathic-Anger Scenario Ending: “Taylor soon finds out that the reason s/he tripped and fell was because a rival had poured a slippery liquid in Taylor’s lane before the race in order to take Taylor’s spot on the qualifying team.”



Vignette 3
“Morgan owns a thriving steakhouse. Morgan is completely dedicated to his/her restaurant, putting in long hours and a considerable amount of money into keeping the restaurant running. Morgan’s reputation has attracted attention from elite restaurant reviewers who have decided to review Morgan’s restaurant. This is an incredible opportunity for Morgan. Unfortunately, Morgan’s staff served steak that made all of the customers – including the reviewers – violently ill. The incident became public, and the Department of Public Health was forced to shut down Morgan’s restaurant due to health violations. Morgan lost his/her cherished restaurant.”

Empathic-Distress Scenario Ending: “Morgan soon finds out that the reason customers got sick was because of a local, unpreventable salmonella outbreak in one of their recent beef shipments.”

Empathic-Anger Scenario Ending: “Morgan soon finds out that the reason customers got sick was because a rival restaurateur tainted Morgan’s beef supply.”


Vignette 4
 “Jamie is a hard-working professional. Jamie’s dream has been to move his family into a beautiful, Victorian-style house in the neighborhood. Over the past 10 years, Jamie has been working overtime and multiple, part-time jobs. Finally, Jamie was able to save enough money to finally move his/her family into the new house. Unfortunately, the house caught fire one night and burned to the ground, just weeks after Jamie and his/her family moved in. Although nobody was injured, all of the family’s possessions were destroyed in the fire, including treasured and irreplaceable family heirlooms. Jamie’s insurance policy application had not yet been processed, so insurance will not cover Jamie for the losses.”

Empathic-Distress Scenario Ending: “Jamie soon finds out that the reason Jamie’s house burned down was because of a freak, unavoidable gas leak that ignited the fire.”

Empathic-Anger Scenario Ending: “Jamie soon finds out that the reason Jamie’s house burned down was because of a neighborhood delinquent who set fire to the home as a cruel prank.”
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
Psychopathy dimensions (summated): primary psychopathy, secondary psychopathy, boldness, meanness, disinhibition, interpersonal manipulation, callous affect, erratic lifestyle, antisocial behavior.
Perceived target anger, sadness, and fear (averaged across three respective components and further averaged across vignettes).
Psychopathy dimensions (conceptualized as IV); perceived target emotional responses (conceptualized as DV)

In accordance with guidelines proposed in Amrhein, Trafimow, and Greenland (2019), we plan to address the limitation of statistical significance dichotomization by focusing discussion of our data on parameter estimates (i.e., effect sizes based on recommendations in Funder and Ozer, 2019). Supplementary statistical information pertaining to compatibility with the null hypothesis (dimensional p-values) and compatibility of effect sizes within the current sample (95% confidence intervals) will be presented for richer insight into the data. Thus, no inferences about “statistical significance” will be drawn.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi:
Psychopathy dimensions (summated): primary psychopathy, secondary psychopathy, boldness, meanness, disinhibition, interpersonal manipulation, callous affect, erratic lifestyle, antisocial behavior.
Vicarious sensitivity for each emotion concept. We will compute “relative discrepancy scores” by subtracting perceived target emotional responses from respective vicarious emotional responses, thereby creating indices of vicarious emotional sensitivity for each emotion. Positive scores represent vicarious emotional sensitivity (i.e., the vicarious response overwhelms the target appraisal), whereas negative scores represent vicarious emotional insensitivity (i.e., the target appraisal overwhelms the vicarious response).
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: In an effort to increase the generalizability of our sample, we will recruit additional male participants so that the maximum female-to-male ratio is 3:2 (vs. 4:1 or greater, for example).
We will aim to recruit at least 300 undergraduates from the University of Alabama’s participant pool. Data will be collected via Qualtrics.

Sample size determinations were based on results in Schönbrodt and Perugini (2013), which indicated that parameter estimates for correlations typically stabilize around N = 250. Because some correlations in the proposed study will comprise difference scores and might require larger sample sizes to ensure reliable estimation, we will aim to recruit at least 300 undergraduates from the University of Alabama’s participant pool. This larger sample will also buffer against potential exclusions due to attrition and/or spurious cases.
Data will be collected until at least 120 males can be collected (but may exceed this number). At no point will data be analyzed before pre-registration or data collection has terminated.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-fourth.fourth.ques:
Psychopathy dimensions (summated): primary psychopathy, secondary psychopathy, boldness, meanness, disinhibition, interpersonal manipulation, callous affect, erratic lifestyle, antisocial behavior.
Emotional congruence for each emotion concept: We will compute “absolute discrepancy scores” by taking the absolute value of each index of vicarious emotional sensitivity and multiplying the result by -1 (for a similar approach to computing empathy, Kraus, Côté, & Keltner, 2010). Thus, higher scores denote greater emotional congruence and, hence, approaches greater “empathy.”

Vicarious anger, sadness, and fear (averaged across three respective components and further averaged across vignettes).
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: Participants will be excluded if (a) they did not complete all measures and/or (b) they fail more than one of three attention checks, which suggests apathetic responding.
